40316708.review:
Onward is basically VR counter-strike. It's 5v5 objective based.

Pros:
+Realistic weapons. Different weapons have to be reloaded differently.

+Large variety of weapons from rifles, lmgs,  shotguns, and snipers

+good community. I've played with several players many times. No toxicity usually

Cons:

-Buggy. I've stood near a wall where half my body glitches through and I get killed. I've fallen through the map multiple times. Many times my soldier in game just stops holding onto his weapon with both hands messing up my accuracy.

-Many weapons completely useless. Game exchanges realism for fun. Sniping is borderline impossible. 

I wouldn't recommend the game for the following reasons:

1. The game is basically hide and seek. It's incredibly difficult to see players since they can glitch most of their body into scenery.  Many times defenders just go to poorly lit spots and sit there.  If you attack and die you will sit for 5 minutes watching your teammates crawl towards the enemy. If you are on defense be prepared to sit in 1 spot and stare at a wall until the enemies come to you.

2. The weapons are completely unbalanced. You will see 90% of players using the standard assault rifles. Many weapons don't hit where the reticle shows on some sights. It takes 2 slow firing shotgun shots to kill someone while it takes 2 shots from an assault rifle that lays down 10 shots per second the same. 

Using the sniper rifles is not viable in game. Snipers either come with no scope and are difficult to aim or come with a 4x or 12x scope. The maps are small so both of these are impossible and pointless to use. You will likely get flamed by your team for using a sniper.

3. Many accessories are just as useless. You can use a flash light or laser sight and both of those will just get you killed in the game of hide and seek.  You can use forgrips and silencers but using them will make you unable to use body armor or AP ammo.

4. Tracking is poor. Many times I barely move my arms to turn and my guy takes his hands off the rifle. Shooting 1 handed basically kills you vs anyone else. That fact it happens so much is ridiculous. 

This game has a lot of potential for being awesome but it also has a lot of issues as well. The lack of viable weapons and items,  the bugs, and excessively slow hide and seek game play take this from a great game to a "meh" shooter. It will likely die once VR gets more competitive shooters. Or for more fun,  go play Rec Room paintball.

40020643.review:
This is the best game in VR so far.  I had it on release day when there were only a couple of maps, one game mode and lots of glitches and frame drops.  Even though it made players sick, it was revolutionary, the DOOM of VR maybe. Since then its community has exploded, the bugs have been mostly worked out, and there are new, well-thought out maps and modes.

Shooters are a natural fit for VR, with its free range of motion to lie prone, toss a grenade, or simply run at your enemy and shoot.  Mil-sim style games like this one are usually not the most popular shooters, but the gritty realism is even more of a natural fit in VR than on a flat screen.  When bullets wizz by you, Onward makes sure you feel it.  When you hear the click of an enemy's grenade on the other side of the wall, it's hard to keep your heart from skipoping a beat.  Onward has realized many of the things that us 20 and 30-somethings have been dreaming about since the very first shooters.

It's exciting to see what a single developer can do in this new medium, and it makes me really excited for the road ahead of VR.

For mil-sim lovers, this is a must-own title for Vive. This game, as great as it already is, still has so much more potential. 

First and foremost, I want to attest specifically to the realism that is the weapon mechanics:
I own several firearms, some of which include an AR-15, M9, and bolt-action rifle. When I enter the firing range mode, it's like I'm operating my own guns at the range - from firing, mag drop, reloading, charging, and select fire, the operation is amazingly realistic - So much so that I've begun using this game for safe operating training before I bring first-time friends/family shooting. 

If you have experience operating firearms, you will be amazed at the realism of this game.
If you've never operated firearms before, you're about to learn how to in great detail.

Other thoughts:
-Put a (quiet) fan in the room - it'll get intense
-Controls may be tough to get at first, and may make you motion-sick, but just take breaks and hang in there.
-Radio and proximity comms work great, but playing in an area with ambient noise (TV on, kids screaming) may give away position to enemy
-Elegant solution to having a map and in-game info as a tablet that can be stored or retrieved from your back 
-Again, this isn't a spray-and-pray, run-and-gun arcade shooter like "CoD." Think "ArmA" instead.

Have fun out there!

39103096.review:
This game is marked Early Access, but it doesn't feel like it. This is one of the best VR games out there, is a VR bestseller according to Steam, and is an excellent example of the full potential of VR. You want to reload your gun? Do it manually as you would in real life. Need to crouch behind a barrier? Get down on your knees. Are you sniping? Lie down on the real floor. This realism really makes this game and every VR developer should pay attention to it. The smooth locomotion via the touchpad is well designed and does not induce motion sickness for most people, so other VR games have copied this "Onward-style" movement control.

The gun mechanics seem very realistic and are unrivaled by any other game (including Pavlov) and the maps are very well designed. The gameplay is balanced via a point system on the loadout and the in-game mechanics, so the matches are very fun and highly dependent on your own skill. The tutorial is very helpful to newbies and the developers (isn't it just one guy?) seem to be moving this game in exactly the right direction. This game also stands out on the small things, such as the environmental noises and the appearance of some fog as you breath out in real life. The overall immersion is just outstanding.

To get good at this game, you need to listen carefully to your surroundings. Be stealthy, coordinate with your teammates via the radio, and learn the maps. You can improve your accuracy with a gun stock to hold your controls as if they were a real gun. Use the tablet and watch to your advantage.

I've been with this game since release, and it is the staple tactical multiplayer shooter for VR so far. None of the other VR shooters can quite capture the nice balance of realism and tactics this game offers. With that being said, it has a lot of issues.

First, it has some optimization problems. A lot of the things people complain about or want added to the game aren't being done because the game is just teetering on the edge of being unplayably optimized, and adding the new features they want will send it over. The game was made by an inexperienced developer, so I can only imagine the spaghetti code mess the game is, and it's gotta be impossible to get it into a decent state at this point without a huge overhaul of the code.

This is evident by the very rigid interactions and gameplay, as well as numerous inconsistent bugs and performance issues. You can only grab your gun one way, with your primary hand on the handle and you can grab the barrel with your offhand. You can't hold more than a single thing at a time. Want to check your one-handed tablet? You have to completely let go of your rifle with both hands, then grab it with your primary (and just your primary) hand. You can only grab a grenade with your primary hand, and pull the pin with your offhand. You can't throw with your offhand.

You can't share equipment between players; it's as if all your equipment doesn't exist to everyone else. Dead body ragdolls aren't synced between players so when you see a dead body as being right in front of you, maybe you're hiding behind it, your opponent sees it as being 5 feet to your left and they can see you clearly.

Besides all of that, there are severe balance issues in the game as well. I've played in the competitive Onward league for 2 seasons now, so I feel qualified to talk about this. There are huge issues with night maps due to defending players (which are always in black) being absolutely invisible in dark areas. The night vision is nearly useless, but not useless enough that you can forego selecting it in your loadout. All it does is turn up the gamma and apply a green filter, which still does absolutely nothing when someone is in a dark corner or room staring you in the eyes.

One of the absolute worst balanced maps is called Subway, which has 2 major chokepoints (stairwells) that the attacking team has to somehow force through. The defending team almost always can get to the chokepoint first, and it's dreadfully easy to defend these chokepoints, but not impossible for the attacking team to make it through. Nevertheless, it's a huge balance issue in competitive play.

Despite all the issues, it's an experience that other games can't offer yet, and one I enjoy a lot. If you're looking for a tactical shooter, Onward is the game to get. I'm sure the game will keep slowly getting improvements and features, but emphasis on "slowly." 

It's only a matter of time before another game is made that captures the same gunplay and tactic feel that Onward has, but by someone or a team that knows what they are doing. It will be a game that has a more flexible and stable codebase, and provide much better, feature-rich gameplay. If the Onward devs don't get their shit together, it won't be longer than a year or so before they lose their playerbase. They're missing out on a lot of potential.

I've only played about 2 hours so far, most of that online. I am really, really impressed. Sure the visuals aren't exactly AAA grade but the guns look and feel amazing. I'm able to pull off single fire kill shots at pretty good distances using a holographic sight and god damn is it satisfying. This is the future of FPS.

EXTENDED FOLLOW UP EDIT:

I'm now nearly 15hrs into this game and I still stand by everything I've said. The controls have gotten even more intuitive as I played, I can reload without looking at my vest, or pull a grenade or pistol from my hip without looking at my vest. My legs and arms get physically strained from playing intense matches over a long period and it's awesome. It feels real.

Ducking for cover feels real, blind firing around corners or over cover feels real. Suppression WORKS because players are scared. When you get suppressed, you lose peripheral vision which is so cool. If you take damage, you start to bleed out and your vision goes black & white and/or blurry until you inject yourself with a stimulant to keep going. (This doesn't give you health back, only gets you back on your feet).

There are a few things I'd like to see changed for the future:
- 4x & 12x Scopes. These are REALLY difficult to use, the sweet spot to see through them is seriously unforgiving and this is really difficult when you're using your hands with 2 VR controllers. I imagine a gunstock makes this easier but they can't be an expected requirement to play the game. I don't know how unforgiving scopes are in real life, but I doubt they are black until you perfectly position your eye ball? I have given up on using them.

- Ammunition in clips representing how many rounds are ACTUALLY inside. Right now they are visually represented as full, or empty. I would like to be able to release my clip, check how many rounds are left then put it back in between fire fights.

- It would be nice to be able to choose left eye vs right rendering for the sake of streaming. Watchers can't see my scope when I ADS on my right eye.

- Binoculars! Due to the resolution limits of current VR headsets, seeing and identifying targets beyond medium range can be really difficult or nearly impossible at times. Having binoculars you can pull from your backpack would really help with this. It could even add to the meta of identifying targets over the radio.

- Tactical Wrist Watch. The wrist watch compass numbers/bearings are great, but I think a more inuitive addition could be to have North,  South, NNW, SE, etc added as well for beginner players.

- More maps would be great! But I'm sure they are coming.

All in all this game gets a solid 9/10 from me for pushing what an FPS should be. I haven't had this much fun with a shooting game since the original COD games. This is the next evolution of immersion.

用HTCVIVE等VR设备完全体现出该游戏的特色，仿真小规模战斗喜欢FPS的基佬们有福气了，虽然刚进游戏时对于移动方式会有些小晕，但是熟悉之后会好很多，可能跟体质有关系吧。

至于游戏性，游戏内可分为5V5模式对抗模式，4人小队VSAI模式，还有个5人模式，目前还没玩。可选兵种有突击兵、机枪兵、特殊兵和狙击手，兵种对于选择主武器有区别，其他没啥区别。突击兵可选M16A4类的突击步枪、机枪兵可选PKM类的机枪，特殊兵可以选择大盾、MK18、MP5类的枪、狙击手可选SV98、svd、MK17类的狙击步枪（PS：狙击枪械分手动和自动，手动需要打一枪拉一下枪栓，很有感觉，但是初期会感觉很别扭哈哈，小技巧就是左手握着枪管，右手松开手去拉枪栓）每个兵种都有8种项目可以选择，分别是主枪械、瞄具、挂件、子弹、手枪类、手雷、防弹衣和夜视镜等。（PS：这里狙击手用X4或者X12倍镜很不友好，比较难索敌，跟头盔手柄配合不太好，个人感觉而已），枪械和挂件还是比较丰富的。
其他小操作如：胸前可拿取手枪、手雷、弹夹和医疗针。空手在背后可拿地图。左肩头用手柄按着可以进行小队通话。头盔上可以用手打开夜视仪。枪械挂件比如战术手电和镭射都可以手动打开或关闭等。总体来说游戏性还是挺好的，作为一个FPS玩家，个人还是蛮推荐的，玩着很带感！

另外在玩的时候注意：第一尽量不要TK。第二要学会使用医疗针救队友，可以扔个烟雾弹掩护下，只要你操作够娴熟够快。

至于个人有点不太满意的地方：
第一个就是网络的问题，经常性的在突突中掉线，或者进房间的时候掉线，因为目前一直是裸连，所以应该是最头疼的问题。当然不排除自己网络的好坏问题了。
第二个就是目前玩的人数不算太多，一般来说选房间能看到的就是1-3个10人对战，2-3个4人小队，1-2个5人游戏，所以遇到好的队友，还是尽量跟着一起多打几局吧。
第三个就是进房间后如果已经开始游戏，等待的时间会稍长一些，这个时候可以选选自己的枪械或者配件磨磨时间吧，也没啥别的好办法啦。

38273033.review:
For a game that is built by one guy, this is one of the best VR experiences available to date.

VR games have largely been shooters; and Onward does just fine as a shooter. What sets Onward apart are all the other interactions, such as grabing a grenade off your belt, pulling the pin, and rolling the grenade into an open door, or laying down in your basement fumbling for a syringe while machine gun fire snaps around you. Reaching up to your shoulder to activate the radio to tell your teammates that you are still alive. There is something sublime about leaning your real body back behind a corner, reaching up to a virtual gun, pulling the magazine out, then reaching into your tactical vest for a fresh mag to slam home. 

Far more than the shooting, it is the supporting actions that prove that VR can be more than a gimmick. We need more games like Onward to prove that there is value in VR. If you spent the money for a headset, you owe it to yourself to play Onward.

And if you  are skeptical of online play, the community is pretty great, welcoming and helpful. And the developer has added cooperative play, and solo play against AI. So there's no excuse.

38066025.review: First 10 or so hours of this game is a blast just trying out new guns and trying to get that first good kill. That being said there are a lot of controls to get the hang of but most of them are easy to pick up on and then they actually feel really comfortable (like you are a real soldier). But the magic of this game is not in the first 10 hours... the magic happens when you begin to become a competent player. Checking corners with your teammates, knowing good spots, reloading under fire. These things give you a sense of incredible realism. There was one experience in particular that really stuck out to me, i found myself moving up a flank when suddenly i came under fire from an enemy player using an LMG. The guns are loud in this game (very realistic sounding) my vision became narrowed and i took cover behind a car ( Laying on the ground in my basement). Bullets rattled off the car over and over, i peaked up over the hood of the car and fired off a few rounds in the general direction of the fire. More rounds started to hit the car, Quickly I knew i had to get out of there but i would never make it across the street to cover. Suddenly i remembered i had a smoke grenade on my chest. I reached down pulled the pin and tossed the grenade over the car and in front of me. I then preceded to scramble across the street where i could rejoin my team on the other side of the map. Ok yes in any first person shooter that is such a lame story, but in VR when you have to think like that and everything feels and seems real, an experience like that can get your adrenal glands pumping. This is hands down the best VR title i have played up until this point. The replay value is fantastic, the dev team listens to the community, and the community is great to play with. I highly recommend getting a VR for just this game alone!

Der Steam-Award möchte, das ich ein Review verfasse. Und wenn: dann für Onward ! :-)

Onward stand nach dem Kauf meiner Oculus Rift noch lange nicht auf meiner Wunschliste.
Die Grafik sah in diversen Videos oder Screenshots nicht soo Einladend aus.
Dann schreckte mich ab, das man nach dem virtuellen Ableben bis zum Rundenende warten muß (das mochte ich noch nie). Und der immer wieder genannte Vergleich zu Arma hielt mich auch ab.
Weil ich mit Arma bisher leider nicht warm geworden bin.

Im Sommer habe ich dann doch zugeschlagen; und seit dem spiele ich Onward wöchentlich!
Und zwar in einer deutschen VR-Community. 


Zu Onward:
Die Grafik ist sogar besser als zuvor angenommen. In VR sieht die Grafik recht ordentlich aus.
Die Waffen sehen sogar fantastisch aus. Sehen sehr real aus. Nur das leichte Gewicht der Touch-Controller sagt mir, das ich keine echte Waffe in der Hand halte :-) 

Das Waffenhandling, die Haptik, das Nachladen und das bedienen der Waffen sind sehr gut und sehr realistisch. Auch der Klang der Waffen ist sehr realistisch.
Überhaupt setzt Onward auf Realismus. Onward braucht keinen Hardcore-Modus. Dieses Spiel ist Hardcore!
Wird man im Kopf getroffen, ist man sofort weg. Wird man am Körper, Beinen, Armen nur angeschossen, wird einem schwarz vor Augen. Ist man heftig angeschossen worden, kann man sich nicht mehr bewegen. Dann muß ein Teamkollege herbei eilen und dich mit einer Spritze wieder auf die Beine stellen. Man kann sich auch selbst mit der Spritze versorgen.
Aber nicht wenn man ausgeknockt wurde.  Man kann dann nur noch nach seinen Teamkollegen rufen, u. hoffen das einer kommt. Hört der Gegner deine Hilfe-Rufe, dann gibt er dir den Rest.

Und dieser Realismus; das ist auch eher der Vergleich zu Arma. Arma ist ja auch eine Simulation mit einem sehr hohem Grad an Realismus.

Von den Maps her gibt es keinen Vergleich zu Arma. Zumindest von der Größe. Und das ist auch gut so bei nur max. 10 Spieler je Server.
Es gibt leider noch nicht sehr viele Maps. Aber unter den vorhandenen Maps, sind schon ein paar außergewöhnlich gute Maps dabei.  Es gibt auch Maps, die im dunkeln gespielt werden. Night Vision an, u. es werde grün und hell :-)

Das Waffenarsenal in Onward ist recht ordentlich. In der Lobby des Servers kann man vor jeder Runde sein Setup auswählen u. mehrere Setups bearbeiten. Und das bleibt dann auch so bestehen, bis man es wieder verändert.
Um die Balance zu gewähren gibt es eine maximale Anzahl an Punkten, die nicht überschritten werden darf.
Beispiel: Möchte man einen Schalldämpfer ausrüsten, fehlen am Ende dann Punkte für eine Handgranate. 

Das warten nach dem vorzeitigen Ableben bis zum Rundenende ist gar nicht soo schlimm. Wenn ich denn vorzeitig ausscheide, kann ich nicht nur den noch lebenden Teamkollegen zuschauen u. auf einer übersichtlichen Map verfolgen, wo sie gerade unterwegs sind; sondern mich mit allen anderen virtuell gefallenen Mitspielern unterhalten.
Und da hatten wir schon eine Menge Spaß :-)

Sobald die nächste Runde startet, kann man sich auf der Map nur noch mit seinen Team-Mitgliedern unterhalten. Aber nur, wenn man noch dicht beisamen ist. Ansonsten kann man den Funk benutzen, um mit seinem Team zu kommunizieren. 
Aber aufgepaßt !  Ist der Feind in der Nähe kann man sich durch Funksprüche (Funkgeräusche) oder Unterhaltungen verraten :-)   Das alleine macht Onward schon sehr interessant. Sowas gibt es nur in VR. (es wird kein Teamspeak genutzt. Voice nur InGame !)


Also, für mich ist Onward das VR-Spiel des Jahres. 


Auslöser für den Kauf der Oculus Rift plus Touch-Controller war ein Youtube-Video über "Arizona Sunshine" (VR-Spiel), das man in VR mit ausgestrecktem Arm und händischer Ausrichtung per echtem Kimme & Korn schiessen und treffen kann.
Das ist ein wahr gewordener Männer-Traum :-)  
Und genau so funktioniert es auch in Onward.
Das ist mit Shooter am Monitor nicht mehr vergleichbar. Das ist VR !


PS:   Für alle, die gerne Paintball spielen:
Kauft Euch eine Rift oder Vive und Onward !   Das ist der Ersatz oder das Trainingsprogramm für Paintball schlechthin.
Tauscht blaue Flecken am Körper gegen Abdrücke einer VR-Brille im Gesicht  :-)

36703168.review:
Onward is a game that pretty much any VR owner should have in their library. Its a mil-sim game with excellent realism (quick kill, good weapon behaviors, wallbanging), interactive weapons (many moving parts, weapon unique reloads), and a strong community (both in active players, and developer support). 

The game is essentially 5v5 combat, with a variety of maps and two main modes for multiplayer (uplink - objective based, and escort -cover a VIP player), and its well populated even at non-peak hours for a VR game. There is a single player component which is just versus bots and a shooting range for practice which matches the amount of content most games of the same genre offer. Additionally it should be noted it is a full locomotion game, and many will often get sickness when first playing until they adapt, to do this it is recommended to  physically move your body (run in place) to reduce this effect until your body adapts. 

The game is in early access, but don't let that fool you, there is more game here than in many games on the market at present, although again it is mostly a multiplayer experience with some single player components. The developer is actively updating the game with new weapons and maps as time passes, so it is well supported (although small team so major updates are infrequent).  

Onward is for many VR early adopters the definitive title and justification of VR as a viable platform. Its one of the few games that you will see in the VR community at present where players exist with 100s of hours of gametime, and as such it is worth the price of admission. I thereby give Onward a full recommendation, its a VR essential which gives you a rush unlike anything I've ever experienced with conventional FPS games.

This is one of the best VR experiences I've had so far. I really love the controls and free movement. The gameplay is extremely well balanced in my opinion. The developer is consistently listening to the community and making improvements which is great. 

I have a few complaints. The level designs, while they do seem balanced and provide for good gameplay for the most part, often feel really sparse. They could use some more decoration. 

The scale of the in game objects feels just slightly off sometimes. Some are better than others in this regard. The streets of Subway feel pretty good for example. 

You're limited to 5 vs 5 and the maps are pretty small. A couple maps I would describe as medium sized perhaps. The maps aren't very numerous either and there is no Steam workshop to add more maps like in the game Pavlov. I would really like to see maybe a 12 vs 12 mode and some nice big maps. Ideally it would be the size and scope of Arma or Battlefield games, but obviously that's expecting too much. 

Some skill based match making would be nice too. I get paired with some super try-hards some times that are into the whole competitive meta game and it's really frustrating because I only have a few hours to play every week. I don't have the time to memorize every pixel of every shooting lane of the maps. Having some player statistics that you could look at for other players could help there.

All in all this game is a fantastic experience despite those minor complaints. It really gives you the feeling that you're a member of a small fire team. If you have a good group of guys, you're going to have the time of your life.

36041159.review:
This is by far my most favorite VR game! This is like if Arma, and Insurgency got together and made a VR game! If you know how to operate real firearms, and can play tactically, then this game is a must buy! 

To start off, the community for this game is great! I see a lot of the same players in the lobbies, which means they are loving it as much as I am. Everyone is very helpful, and friendly to players new and old. You will play with some that want to plan their attack, and others that just want to rush the objective. Whichever way you and your team approach it, you are bound to have some fun! Although, I will say that just like every other game, you will see some rotten eggs. Luckily, those players can be kicked. So far though, the bad eggs are a minority, because the barrier to entry for VR is still too pricey for mainstream players (trolls, kids, etc..).

Aside from the community, the gameplay itself is really great! In fact, with the combination of the community, and gameplay, this game really shines among all other VR games I have played! I have never played a game besides Arma, where I have seen so much teamwork! This is like the definitive Military Simulator! I have a hard time going back to 2D games like Arma after playing this. I know that is a bold comparison, especially when Arma offers vehicles, and so much more, and is 2D. But being able to actually hold your guns virtually is amazing, and being able to operate with them as you would in real-life is also amazing! The realism is yet to be matched in any other military style game I have played besides Hot Dogs, Horseshoes, and Handgrenades. But that game is single-player only so it also cannot really be compared to Onward. Although, if you had to pick between Bullets and More, Pavlov, or Onward for a VR FPS which is online; I would pick Onward any day of the week! Pavlov is like Counter Strike VR. Not much realism in that one aside from the guns. Same goes for Bullets and More. 

No 2D game gives you this much situational awarness and control! You can sit, lay-down, peak from walls, and any shooting stance comfortable for you will work! Currently you can play five versus five in a Search and Destroy style game type, or escort the VIP gametype. For the most part everyone I have played with enjoys the S&D style mode, called "Uplink". The VIP mode gets the least love, because whichever side is protecting the VIP is now missing a capable fighter, because the VIP has their loadout replaced with a pistol only. I agree with some of the other players that the game could use some other gametypes, but I still love this game regardless! 

Honestly, for what I paid for I feel that I have gotten my money's worth and then some! For $25, I now have about 25 hours in this game. In VR time, that is a lot of standing... and crouching, and dodging virtual bullets! I have played with people that have a thousand plus hours in this game! Crazy as that sounds, it is true! Like I said, I see a lot of "regulars" while playing this game. Everyone comes to recognize eachother's name after a while. You might join a lobby, and four of the people in it are people you have played with a day, week, or month ago! Although, there are also constantly new people joining the ranks everyday! So, if you are reading this, then why not you?!?! Seriously, if you have a VR headset, and you want a great shooter with a great community, and lot of replay value; then get this game!

I literally cannot recommend this game enough! I highly recommend you get this game before the price increases! To me, this game is better than Arizona Sunshine, and most of the other largely popular VR games. This game really transforms the whole concept of first person shooter! You feel like you are literally in a room with the people you are playing with! When you first play this game you can get so immersed that the gun shots coming at you may scare the living heck out of you! 

If you are still reading any of this review, then maybe I convinced you enough! Buy it! It will be totally worth it! 


See you on the battlefield comrades!

35180335.review:
Video games, for the longest time, have given us a window into a make-believe world where anything is possible.  VR has done something amazing and, instead of looking in from the outside, has placed us INSIDE THE GAME! Onward does an amazing job of making me feel immersed in a military combat situation. The ambient sounds and effects are subtle but effective and realistic.  The implementation of the inventory system is as real as it gets.  Your magazines, smoke grenades, flashbangs, side arm etc are placed specifically on your virtual body.  Look down and you see your equiptment right where you'd expect in real life. Reloading requires you to drop the magazine from your gun, reach over and grab a new magazine, insert it into your gun and operate the loading mechanism. Going from pressing a single button in traditional games to actually interacting with your inventory ads a level of immersion that just has to be experienced to understand. 

If you want to imagine what it's like playing this game, just imagine what it's like in real life to engage in combat. The game modes are what you'd expect. There is an objective game mode which requires one team to arrive at an "uplink" destination and send a code.  Another game mode requires a single, randomly selected player, to arrive at an extraction point marked by smoke without being eliminated by the other team. The "VIP" in this escort game mode has only a pistol and the support of the remaining members of the team to get to the extraction point. 

This game is a work in progress but make no mistake about it, this game is easily a stand-alone game in it's current form and will only get better as time goes on.  I love playing this game and can't wait to see what lies in store for us next.

EDIT: I'm playing this game on the Rift with two cameras.  I have the game settings to allow for room scale.  This means that to turn around I need to turn my whole body around.  I also have my cable suspended above me, works great BTW. I was concerned with turning around so much that I would twist the cable up.  Luckily, I came across a program created by a user called TurnSignal.
This program displays an image on the ground below you that twists up as you turn so you can keep your cable from becoming twisted up.  I found it helpful and wanted to share.

I played this from an Oculus Rift.

I'm one of those who took advantage of the free Onward weekend. I never bought this game previously as I had some concerns from things I had heard (horrible community, motion sickness) but I was intrigued at playing Call of Duty VR so I gave it a go. 

Onward's positives far outweigh the negatives that I experienced. It is what I had hoped it would be and while some of my concerns were justified, it did not make the grave mistake of frustrating or making the new player angry and I put in some time to learn this thing. I was not so kind to BAM. 

To be brief, you need to learn this game before you play it. It's not like learning Elite Dangerous, but it is more of a learning curve than Robot Recall. It's war and it's unforgiving. That means following through with the tutorial, spending some time in the shooting ranges/solo campaigns, and reading some tips online. That helped a lot and is probably why I was not on the recieving end of any significant verbal abuse. I was awful for my first couple of days - you could find my corpse a minute into any game with a bullet in the head - and it wasn't until day 3 that I finally pulled through some very gratifying multiplayer games. There is a clear discrepency in skill levels between newbs and vets.

I won't describe the war-play, that is evident from the trailers. You should know that you need to learn how to load the guns but that turned out to be very easy. What I will talk about are the concerns I had going in. First off, the community has a notorious reputation for being verbally abusive. And yes, I have heard some of that first hand now. The devs need a better way to police online speech and behavior beyond the existing measures. Onward is not the only game with this issue, nearly any VR multiplayer has it. Even though the racism level is high (the #1 issue I noticed), there are a lot of very good and helpful community members who took no part in that. It seems you might have to "fish" for the right room to join if you are uncomfortable. I am going to call this a growing pain of the VR community at large and not an indictment of this game. People will say anything if they feel there are no repercussions. 

Second worry I had was with motion sickness. I am sensitive to it and this game does not use teleportation. But you know what? I did not get any. I played for hours last night and I felt fine. Maybe my VR legs are slowly kicking in but there has been no issue with locomotion at all. Maybe the in-game tension is enough of a distraction that the brain doesn't have time to press the barf button. 

One thing to note to my Oculus using friends: There are some Steam-related things you should be aware of. First, you must launch this game through Steam even though it will appear in your Oculus library. If you don't, there is no multiplayer and I couldn't even get the shooting range to load. Second, launch the game from inside the Steam VR home room. I don't know why, but if I launch through my library, I have audio issues (All audio goes to my monitor regardless of my settings and my mic will not function). I have yet to experience that issue when launching from the Steam home room and that has been a fix for a couple of different games now. And one more note on the audio: Make sure you double check the Steam VR audio settings. Make sure sound is being sent to your Rift and the mic is set to Rift on launch and back to where you want it to be when you quit Steam VR. This has been reset randomly a few times now so save yourself the agony of having to reload and double check before you launch.

34944364.review:
After the recent Oculus Rift Sale in which I acquired a headset for myself I was in need of some games beyond DCS and the free experiences you can get. "Onward" was definitely my first pick as I had seen it been covered in numerous youtube play throughs and so on.

If there is one thing to note, most VR indie games for the most part look similar in some regards (probably in part due to the engine they use) but they certainly dont all play the same. Onward is one of the few that stands out.

Onward sets the bar for VR realistic shooters, as its mechanics force you into the difficult tasks of combat, without having overtly complicated mechanics. If you are new to VR, keep in mind this may be a little offputting initially due to moving with an analog stick or pad and motion sickness may set in. But its executed well enough to not be too overwhelming and with consistent sessions you can easily find yourself not even feeling off in the slightest.

What makes this game fantastic is the literal responsibilty for everything you have to do. If you run out of bullets in the mag, you have to change mags yourself. You throw the grenades, you are the one holding your breath to take the critical shot on the target. Everything in this game comes down to you, and to see a game so involivng is fantastic, especially without over complicated in game menus and options to choose from. thats the power of VR. I still struggle to realise I have to pull the pin out of the grenade before I use it!

What is not so great is probably the current lack of content and other similar things. Of course, it is still an early access game so its less the fact of criticism and more the issue of when will more content arrive, rather than what. Guns are good but need more variety of sound and polish. More maps, and maybe slightly more detail on said maps would go a long way. AI can either be too stupid or too accurate on the difficulties available and maybe need a bit of an overhaul from 2 states (alert and hunting) to a variety and more objective based singleplayer/coop would bring it out of the ground. Multiplayer is good but requires maybe more players, roles, support methods like mortars (vehicles maybe??) and so on. Glitches, bugs and other issues will surely be ironed out over time.

Most of what is stated above is far from being added to the game, but with further development this could be the greatest VR realistic shooter on the market.

Arguably, early access games are a gamble. But considering the lack of substantial product available on the VR market this is definitely and excellent choice for those who are willing to push their VR capacity, or those who are interested in MilSims. Either way, you will enjoy this game with all it has to offer at such an early stage let alone see what is yet to come!

34364471.review:
Onward is a military first person shooting simulator that gives you weird tingly feelings in the nether regions of your pants that your parents warned you about as a pre-pubescent teen.

This game brings the true glory to what a virtual reality shooting game should be.

There’s no progression system or story line but that’s one of the perks of this game. It isn’t mean to be a Call of Duty clone but more based on strategy then a spray-and-pray shooter.

Weapons are balanced with a fixed point system along with your kit load-out so no one player ever feels to OP. 
Communications are open channel mics and radio coms located on your character making it very easy to spot, target, and eliminate threats. 

The tunnel vision from being fired at to the heart beat pounding in your ears will have you on edge as every corner you turn; every room you enter, every step you take brings you one step closer to victory or defeat.

Here’s some game play of the recent map that Downpour Studios just unleashed for their Operative mode. 

No commentary or silly clips just straight up game play of me vs 16 bots.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HcoyHwCCiFA

Now let’s talk about the cons because no game is without sin.

All the maps I’ve come across have regions where you basically “blackout” and the screen goes dark. The only way to get out of these blackout zones is to move around until you can see again or someone takes you out by shooting you.

I don't recommend this for OCULUS RIFT users. The game claims Rift support, but in reality this is clearly an afterthought for more sales.

31512952.review:
-I dont normally comment on games but this deserves one. Its amazing.

-This is a fact.

-Best VR game out there. The gameplay basically feels like CS source had a bastard baby with ARMA 2. But that isnt even accurate because VR is involved. 

-Its better than both. Place yourself phycsically inside the ARMA 2 or cs battle with bullets raining down around your head while you try to stay calm and return fire or pop a smoke to book it. You can commit friendly fire by shooting your own team because you forgot your color or you panicked. There is no other indicator beside looking at your pad or the color of the guy. Or go completely Batman with a silencer and hiding in the shadows. You can actually follow near by player positions simply based on sound. By listening to him walk, talk, reload, or any other action that might cause a sound you can follow positions easily. Remeber local chat is always enabled so enemies can hear you and your family/friends/pet in the background too. 
Thats just some of the the crazy situations that this game places you in. 

-FIrst games will be rough becuase you have to unlearn many old game mechanics. For instance there is not an auto aim feature that provides bullet drift towards a target. You have to literally line up your sights and fight recoil like a real gun. Spray and pray is just that. YOU spray and hope to god it hits something and in general you wont if you do that. Dont be the new guy that goes lmg, p90, or bolt action sniper without learning the nuances of reloading and charging them. They are more complex then the other guns and new players need to just learn the basics. 

- Protip - If you can reliably reload it, its a good gun. Seems simple but as said before new people forget you cant really pick up every gun and work them all the same. 

-After 150 hours I built my own stock that can release both hands to free float to throw nades or use the pistol and quickly return to locked position for rifle use. I recommend doing this after a few dozen hours in bc it is the next step in getting better at Onwards and basically makes long range a viable option. 

-Community is generally great. There are a few issues with the offical discord negating in game chat and players able to get to odd areas but in general those matches are 1/1000. If you need a help or a tip they will generally help but you have to try. If you arent talking and just standing at spawn trying to figure things out. Everyones gonna have a bad time and you will get kicked. Although if you are just standing at spawn and are asking for help and what not, thats not too bad. A few sessions in the fireing range learning to run and reload are crucial. The rest you learn in time. 

-Protip untill its patched out - if you stick your head through the bars of a window and walk through it in RL you can move through the window. This is the one exploit I dont consider cheating bc it take at least 20 sec to properly do it and that about accurate for opening then throwing yourself out a window. Go for it.

-P.S. - A large (cheap) circulation fan blowing across the play space does wonders for keeping cool and preventiung fog build up on lenses if thats an issue for you.

Laying down in the game by laying down in your actual room is just ridiculously good. For example I had a moment where I saved myself by going prone in front of a barricade while I was under fire by an M249 in a two story building.
Also the head and hand tracking allows you to give signs with your head or hand and a lot of players use that online.

The VoIP system is split into two different channels. There is a walkie talkie and a local channel (open mic). The enemys can always hear you talking when they are close to you which creates a lot of awesome and intense moments for example when you hear someone talking and you give your teammate a sign with your hand to tell him where you want to move silently to take him out.

The community is probaly by far the best I've ever seen in a multiplayer FPS game. I think that's also because people are more willing to talk because of the open mic ingame and the high costs of getting into VR causes that mainly very interested players will be in the game.

But honestly not one round passes without a single laugh because something great happened or somebody just tells a funny joke. The players are friendly to each other, they often greet themselves and in general you just see that everyone has so much fun playing this game. 
Also you often meet the same people because of the small VR playerbase.

If you own an HMD or you have enough money to afford one I can only recommend to get Onward. It's by far the most fun and the best experience you can get in multiplayer FPS at the moment and shows what the future for FPS games can look like!

30739054.review:
This game so insanely fun!  Without the usual push-to-talk option, players are encouraged more so than usual to talk to each other, be it in the lobby waiting for the game to start, while next to each other in-game, or over the radio in-game.  Rememeber though - If your team can hear you talking and the enemy is close enough to you, they can hear you talking too!

Once you've selected your loadout for the current map and team composition and the map loads, you have 16 seconds to discuss tactics with your team, or - as a lot of people seem to do - just fire at each other and throw grenades because you don't take damage during this time.  Once the 16 seconds is up, you have 6 minutes to either capture the objective (involving going to a small satellite dish and using your tablet to input a code, while avoiding getting your face shot off and teabagged while you're down), defend the objective (depending on which team you are on for that round, which is switched after each round), or just take out the opposing team before they have the chance to complete their objective or take you and your team out.

The gameplay itself is very immersive, with accurate feeling bullet drop and other gunnery mechanics.  When the time comes to reload, you have to eject your mag, reach to your spare mag (if you have one), grab it and put it into the gun, and then cock the gun before you can fire again - Or you can switch to your other gun or even a knife if you don't have time to reload or just want to feel like a badass rambo player.

This is by far the most fun game I've played in a VERY long time, and it's always been because of the players that you come across; sure you always get the team killers, and trolls, and those guys that go AFK as soon as a match starts, but the vast majority are willing to work together, and enjoy having a laugh.  Highly recommend for anybody wanting to have fun in VR, especially if you want to play with HTC Vive and Oculus Rift players alike.

30050080.review:
So you got a shiny new VR headset. What do you buy? Sure you gotta pick up your Labs and Job Simulators to break in the hardware, then various games to test a bunch of different gun and swordplay mechanics, then visit Rec Room for a social multiplayer experience.

But none of these hold a candle to Onward and just how robust a game it really is. For a simple title with a few maps, one mode, some bugs, and developed by only one guy, it's remarkably polished and the attention to detail is exquisite. Even better, it's an absolutely compelling multiplayer VR game relying on simple, but immersive and effective mechanics.

For a point of comparison, think Arma meets Counter-Strike, and for those of you who tried out Hot Dogs, Horse Shoes, and Hand Grenades with your fancy HMD gizmo, you'll feel like you discovered H3's hidden multiplayer mode. The concept is that it's realistic 4v4 military-simulator first-person-shooty combat with large maps and one mode, "War", where attackers have to hack a satellite dish while the opposite team tries to defend it. While this all sounds relatively simple, it's the execution and immersion that makes this game a genuine cut above.

When you need to reload, you have to manually eject the clip, grab a new one off your kevlar vest, put it into the gun and load the chamber. If a teammate gets incapacitated (as opposed to plain dead), you have to grab a revive syringe off your jacket, hold it over their body, hold the trigger button, then push in the trackpad button like you would with a real syringe. You can stand, crouch, and prone realistically and duck behind cover while your player model seems to accurately, and realistically track, every movement you make. Contacting your teammates is also given a dash of realism, as you can hear them when they're close, but when they're far away you have to bring your hand to your shoulder to use your radio, and of course, they can't respond when they're dead, potentilly even killed by your own hand! When you need to navigate a map or relay a location to your teammates, you have a tablet device you pull from a back pocket as well as a wristwatch as directional compasses to point out to your team where in relation enemies are to you. Even capturing the object is integrated into the gameplay, as you have to pull out your tablet device, read a code displayed in your tablet, and then go into a keypad to manually type it in in order to win the game. All those are just the mechanics built around a very well-polished and satisfying bit of simulated gunplay!

The best part? The game does all this without any extra button commands or a single piece of UI or HUD to operate your natural movements, instincts, and combat-related information. Couple this with some excellent sound design (and a really good subdued soundtrack on top of that), very detailed models and varied, detailed maps, it all comes together as a seamless experience. You'll wind up feeling like you're really there in the heat of battle, where one wrong move could get you killed. There are no Classes or Perks to be found here.

The maps available are also suprisingly solid. Most of the maps are assymmetric, and rely on using landmarks in order to navigate or call enemy positions. There's also a lot of interplay with verticality (though unfortunately the highest building you can climb is no more than three stories high) and long ranges that make for intense sniper shoot-outs. Close-quarters combat also can work well in Subway, which has a street level and a subway section transitioning from long-distance firefights to cramped quarters. There's even a solid mostly-symmetric map in the form of Suburbia which creates quick confrontations and intense indoor-to-outdoor combat.

That's not to say the game isn't perfect, however. As of the time of this writing, the game is short on maps sporting 3 unique maps, and 2 others with day/night variants. War is also the only mode available in the game, and there's no matchmaking nor leaderboard components to add to the competitive scene. There's also no way to customize load-outs outside of pre-matches for quick selections of favored gear. It'd be nice to tweak these while you're dead and waiting for the round to end, on top of maybe some more physics toys to mess around with or a simple shooting range to practice while you wait. There's also some getting used to required for the trackpad/thumbstick-based movement that can lead to motion sickness if you're easily prone to that. There's no blink mechanics here!

But what's interesting is that the mechanics are so tightly and well-constructed, it makes up drastically for these shortcomings and only shows potential for future modes to be built around such a solid framework. In fact, the strong community in the game came up with a few good ideas of their own such as hostage rescues, pistols or knives-only, no night-vision in night maps, and more. It's exciting to think what things might be like if these kinds modes were incorporated into the game with others to round out the very well-made War mode. Higher player counts could also make for interesting matches on the larger maps.

Onward is a compelling and astounding accomplishment in the forray of VR shooters, and is a remarkable proof-of-concept in a multiplayer title for hardcore VR gamers. And it's done by a single man.

VR needs more innovators like the mind behind Downpour Studios, because Onward, even in Early Access, is an incredible achievement of superb game design wrapped up in an affordable and enjoyable replayable multiplayer package at a well-placed price. This is a must-have for any Vive or Oculus Rift w/ Touch owners looking to take a fun, tense, immersive peek into the future of VR gaming.

FIrst of all : I was prepared to not like Onward. At its core it is a mid/late 2000's purely multiplayer tactical FPS. While I enjoy the genre, I am always a bit weary of the crowd it attracts, There was also the issue of movement. Everybody and their aunt is raving about Onward movement system being super awesome and honestly, I am also weary of hype. 

So ... how did it fare against my relatively negative expectations? Pretty well. The movement system works okay for me, but I am not prone to VR sickness to start with. It is still a bit unwieldly, especially running seems to be of the hit and miss variety, but all in all it works. The gameplay and visuals are exactly what I expected : if it was a 2D game there wouldn't be much to talk about. As it is in VR though, the gameplay transcend its roots and become seriously engrossing. The visuals are not super detialled, but the framerate (on an i5-6600, GTX 1070) is perfectly stable, which is much more important in that case (especially in conjunction with the movement system).

And now to the multiplayer aspect. There are no bots nor single player mode in Onward, so you really have to play and interact with other people. This results in two problems : first of all, you need to find a game to join, and secondly, you can only hope you won't be playing with griefers who only want to spoil the game for everybody. 
I didn't find a game to join. All were full which I found irritating and disappointing. In retrospect, this was ctuially a *good* thing. It means that there is a healthy (for a VR game) playerbase. Nevertheless I decided to start a server and check out the maps solo. Within 30 seconds of creating a  room I was joined by 5 other players (which became 7 on the second round). Some of the players were as new as me, but everybody was extremely friendly and helpful. It was MUCH better than I had expected, and it was, most importantly, *FUN*

tl;dr : your standard tactical FPS but in VR, with an interesting (although still not perfect) movement system and a healthy and *friendly* playerbase. Highly recommended if you are looking for that kind of game!

29931793.review:
I urge you to check out the video review as I go over even more about what makes Onward awesome  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UvHv1ET7wYM


Regardless of how old you are, there's a good chance you've dove deep into a first person shooter at some point. Even if you're well versed in the realm of PC M+KB shooters, you really haven't come close to the kind of freedom Onward provides you with your actions. Now, thanks to the Vive (or Oculus Touch if you swing that way) you're awarded the ability to be in a virtual war like never before.

Now you get to duck for cover while under fire. You fumble with this new gun you never picked before now, cursing the day you ever thought you liked the Aug. You say "fuck it," standing up off of your living room floor while gripping your side arm. You move Onward blasting at the man dressed in black. He disappears behind a bush and you ready yourself to finish him... Victory appears in front of you. You won the round and saved the day. Not with mouse clicks and key presses, but by literally pointing that glock at that dude’s face. Onward is littered with moments like this that would be just another “meh” kill in Call of Duty or whatever into a heart pumping battle to the fucking death.

It’s really great, guys.

The biggest downside is that there's some downtime between rounds, though that should motivate you to try hard to not get shot, stabbed or blown up. You also need your VR legs (while also not being susceptible to motion sickness) to handle the movement.  I barely count this as a negative because the game is early and thus constantly in flux but there is some annoying glitches and rough edges here and there. Certainly nothing game breaking though or anything that would stay my excitement for Onward. Some would also classify the steeper-than-average learning curve as a negative but personally I find that to make it all the more rewarding when you finally do start kicking ass regularly. 

Onward is arguably the best shooter in VR right now and anyone even vaguely interested in seeing how this genre has progressed -- as well as a glimpse into the future of what other VR FPS's can offer -- needs to give it a shot. It's damn fun, damn rewarding, and damn worth your money.

Without them, you just kinda hold both hands in the air awkwardly as you wobble them around trying to keep your aim still. Imagine you have a large cardboard tube. You know, like the ones that wrapping paper comes on. Imagine holding it by the end, a foot away, and trying to look through it. That's what aiming in this game feels like. They need to implement some kind of auto-level system, where if you raise your weapon to your face, it will automatically raise or lower it so you're looking through the sights. This is the first VR game I've played that has really nailed the FPS openworld stucture. Locmotion is intuitive and not sickness-enducing, crouching or hiding for cover all works well, weapons etc work as you'd expect. Its a lot of fun and - once you get used to the level layouts - becomes very tactical very quickly.

I hope the devs upgrade for more players as the maps would easily support 8 or 12 per side - and that would make for a more fun experience as the only downside is that you can walk around for a long time without seeing anyone and then the briefest of firefights and its over. In that regard its very much like counterstrike - so if you are expecting a shooting frenzy this is not it. That said, it can be very rewarding accordingly and even with 4 players on one side, commerardery (sp?) builds up quickly.

The only real criticism I have is not really the game's fault. Any players more than a virtual 150 yards away are represented by so few pixels on your headset that you cannot always tell which side they are on - there are simply not enough pixels to allow your eyes to differentiate between dark khaki and black colours of the opposing clothes. This will improve with hardware resolution over time, but in the meantime maybe a 'garish' mode could be introduced where players were more brightly coloured (red/blue) to help a little until then (I appreciate this would give a tactical advantage so perhaps would have to be applied to everyone as an option for that game session).

29658229.review:
tl;dr If you're OK with early access/don't have a toaster/can afford it Onward is a must buy.

I'll start with community, SO NICE - Onward is a really difficult game to learn (for the better) so if it had a cancerous community that would screw the game outright but every game I've been in, from even fights to getting owned by experts, the players have been kind and helpful. Don't get me wrong, this is Milsim paced, so if you stand up when you should be eating floor you're getting your head blown off, but your team won't be too mean about it and people will explain what you did wrong. Questions (especially how do I reload/run) are expected, as long as you ran through the firing range at least once. Anyway, I want to lean on that - great people to play the game with and games always running, so if you enjoy the game, you won't be put off by who you have to play it with.

As for the game, it's basically COD/Arma but MilSim paced/with one life. You fire pretty realistic looking/feeling weapons, including realistic reloading/grenade proceedures which keep the game from becoming a nade fest. Ammo is restricted, and most fights you won't use more than one magazine anyway because the sound design is wicked good in this game - shooting like a maniac, running and hopping around, talking... these things will get you killed. Some maps are wide open and your whole team may get sniped by one guy if you're not careful, others like subway are more chaotic. 

The shooting on oculus is good and responsive - and the controls, while complicated, are great for the touch - I never thought the controlls killed me when I died and shots went where my iron sights told me they'd go. You do want to have a clear room area and not be embarassed to go prone or crouch though - cover matters. Shots around walls, over cover, hiding, etc are important and your spouse is going to laugh at you as you try to achieve them, be warned.

Movement is touchpad based, and may make some people sick but it doesn't bother me.

Graphics are good on my pretty good computer - I turned them to the lower setting but that's more for framerate than anything (i7, 970) - and the full graphics are pretty great for VR though will require a decent rig if you want to use them. 

Right now it's only 4 on 4 but they plan to expand that to (12 on 12?) squad on squad as the bugs get kicked out, of which there aren't that many. Content is a bit thin but it's early access so NBD.

So yeah, really fun game, great community, a lot of potential.

・一部初見だと分かりにくい操作解説のため、基本操作ガイドを作成しました。参考までに。
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=847891675

対人(マルチプレイ)型、リアル系操作のVRサバイバルゲーム(FPS)である。
　オブジェクト防衛側と攻撃側に分かれたルールとなっている。MAPはそこまで広くは無いが、現状のVRの物理的な視界範囲を考えた場合、この位が適切であると考えられる。
　移動形式はパッド移動であるため、対人がメインとなる本作においても違和感なく移動できた。自分はVR含めゲームでほぼ酔ったことが無いのであまり参考にはならないが、本タイトルにおいて酔うことはなかった。ただし、酔い易い方はこの移動形式に関しては要注意となる。
　対人戦以外でも、ソロで開始可能なシューティングレンジが用意されており、操作の確認が可能である。
　ガジェットは回復用注射器一本、投げ物(選択可能でフラグやスモーク等)、ボディアーマーか暗視装置、ハンドガン(選択可能)、の他に主兵装は兵科毎にいくつか用意(アサルトライフル、ライトマシンガン、サブマシンガン、スナイパーライフル等)されており、レーザーサイトや照準器等といった部分の簡単なカスタム項目が用意されている。
　武器のリロードはワンタッチではなく、マグキャッチを押しながら(押す操作をしながら)マガジンを引き抜き(一部装備でこの操作は不要)、換えのマガジンを装着した後コッキングレバーを引いて初弾を装填する必要がある。
　また、フォアグリップを保持する操作をしないとまともにリコイルコントロールできなかったり、グレネードはピンを引き抜く操作が必要だったりと、細かい部分でコアな仕様となっている。ちなみに、タクティカルリロードの場合は初弾装填操作が不要だったり、チャンバーに弾が入っている状態でコッキングレバーの操作をした場合は、チャンバー内の弾丸が排出されたりと芸が細かい。
　当然ターゲットを狙う際の精密射撃では、ダットサイトやスコープ等を装備していない場合リアサイトとフロントサイトをきちんとあわせないとまともに弾が飛んでいかない。
　ちなみに、回復用注射器の操作が分かりにくいが、注射器装備後に自分または味方の身体に刺さっている状態で、“トリガーを押しながらパッド部分を押す操作をすることで回復が可能”となっているので参考までに。
　VRである程度コアなマルチプレイFPSが楽しみたい方で、酔いに強い方には個人的には是非おすすめしたいタイトルである。

In Onward VR, you are no longer on the outside, looking in through a monitor. 

You are IN there, on a true battlefield.

Simply amazing. Controls feel natural, gunplay is satisfying, defeat feels fair, and victory tastes like ambrosia.

The locomotion in this game is a ground-breaker for the fledgling VR community and should be the standard that all VR games are to be compared to. Crouching, prone, standing, running are all intuitive and take almost no time to get used to. All controlled by the touchpad, you can walk, run, sprint, and even crawl. Because of the direction of your locomotion being decided by the direction of your non-dominant hand, you almost never get motion-sickness. 

*There is NONE of the teleporting that the other shovelware-tier VR games have*

(And truly, if you do get motion sickness, sell your HMD and never touch VR again, because you and your teleporting cancer are going to kill VR gaming) 

Taking out items from the chest harness may be difficult at first, but the inclusion of a shooting range for training can help hone your reflexes. I've spent at least 4 hours in total in the shooting range practicing "cutting the pie", going around corners, sniping, point shooting, and of course, reloading. I've gotten to the point where I can reload an SMG or assault rifle on reflex in less than 2 seconds, something I can say that I am mildly proud of.

This game rewards not only physical prowess and fine dexterity through gunplay, but also teamwork and effective communication. Therefore, when two teams are equal in marksmanship, superior tactics will decide who comes out victorious.  Because of this, skill in this game is not a point and click adventure like most FPS games, but a test and display of superior body and mind. Every victory and every defeat in a multiplayer game only serves to make you better as a player. 

The community is second to none so far, although with the Oculus Rift compatability released, there have been an influx of Christmas jerks who have been nothing but toxic. The "twitch.tv" crowd is starting to jump onto Onward as welll, unfortunately.

Truly the first killer app for the HTC Vive.

Let me just begin by congratulating the (SINGULAR) developer Dante, who I do not know personally, on creating an absolutely fantastic VR title, and in my opinion solving the locomotion problem for VR in general. Other games should be taking notes of the way touchpad movement is implemented in this game. Again, I totally regret not getting this game on release because its just so damn good and has all the replayability of a conventional couch first person shooter x10. The VR experience just adds something unquantifiable to the shooter genre, as with all VR games you just have to play it to believe it i'm afraid.

To me, the best feature of the game, and definately the most important thing in VR for the tech to have some staying power, is how player locomotion is handled, it's what will elevate the countless numbers of wave shooters, teleportation type games and chapter based stories to a level where a game is not only engaging in the virtual reality sense, but is also capable of letting the player explore a living breathing world by themselves in a more natural way, and better draw the player in to a deep, rich narrative, because the player got there by themselves, they weren't placed there to watch a scripted scene run its course. 

Now, just to be clear i'm not saying that this game has any of those things, i'm sorry if I've mislead but this is a tactical multiplayer shooter that has its sights firmly on the milsim enthusiasts rather than the call of duty, arcade shooter type players. However, I think every kind of fps lover will adore this game. There is no story to be found here, (expect the epic and equally hilarious moments you'll want to tell anyone that will listen) it's purely a multiplayer shooter. But the foundation this game is built on, the locomotion, is fundamental to this game for it to work, and revolutionary for VR games going forward. Before now, touchpad controlled locomotion felt like such an inelegant way to solve the problem i honestly didn't think it possible for me to fully enjoy a game with such controls. But holy crap, Dante has nailed it. Here's why -

Before the Vive released I was following it's development intently, and despite a major concern of motion sickness, (Which I'm not great with) I preordered anyway and hoped for the best. I'd never experienced any VR before, and was so happy to find it didn't have me immediately being thrown out of the experience by making me feel sick. Admittedly, after maybe 40 minutes to an hour I needed a break from it, and over time I feel I've built up a pretty strong stomach when it comes to VR. In the beginning, I felt some games were just too much to handle, such as Windlands, which I can now play with relative comfort. Feeling fairly confident I could now handle the touchpad controlled locomotion of onward, I purchased the game. When I tried the game for the first time, i had a friend round who had never experienced any VR before that day. Project Cars and Elite Dangerous both made him feel a little queasy, so after I'd played a few rounds of onward and passed the Vive to him I was expecting the movement to throw him straight away. He said it felt weird...once. After that, he never mentioned it again other than to say he'd quickly got used to it, and not once did it make him feel sick. I'm sure that any VR owners, whether they have an iron stomach or not will appreciate how huge that is for VR. Honestly, when i'd played a round in complete comfort it was like a eureka moment, like this was the gamechanger I'd been waiting for whilst getting a little bored of wave shooters and other simplistic and non innovative ways of designing VR games.

For me personally, the key is having the touchpad direction controlled separately to the looking direction. Games where that is not the case, and you move forward only with the pad but control direction by looking totally throw me, it feels like the floor is being pulled out from under you and you're being dragged along. Totally unnatural and completely removes you from the experience. Because you are able to glance over your shoulder whilst knowing in advance which direction your body will travel feels so much more natural. For me, an absolute game changer.

Okay, wow. Locomotion aside, here's other great reasons to buy.

It is one of the most pleasant online experiences I've had on any game, across every platform I've ever played. Everyone is there to have a blast and its such great fun. I've also found that anyone who goes against the friendly atmosphere is ignored or voted to be kicked, usually with things like insulting other players. Things like teamkills are usually forgiven with laughter because the game is so much fun. It's like being in the same room as players as you see their character bent over in hysterics when something funny happens, and it just adds another level of immersion when you see something like that, hearing an actual persons laughter whilst seeing their actual bodily reaction in real time when they can be from another continent is so strange, like skyping someone inside a tron like world.

Having all your gear attached to your body, once you have understood what individual buttons on the controllers are for, leads to an extremely intuitive experience, weapons function as you would expect, as does all other equipment, meaning you are able to guess how you access and control tools and features, and because you must manually reload weapons yourself instead of hitting a reload button these are a very natural feeling process as well. It also adds an extra level of pressure and calculation to your game, the pressure of being caught short by an enemy whilst reloading as it is no longer a scripted and predictable event, and the calculation the player must make before reloading as to whether it is worth  being personally vulnerable and also being unable to help teammates versus having a few extra bullets in your magazine.

No HUD means a much more immersive and realistic experience.

The attention to detail is phenomenal, you may try to trip the developer up by testing certain gun's functions versus their real life counterparts, and it seems he has thought of everything. Things like being able to see a bullet in the chamber, being able to empty a pistol by cocking the slide enough times, one in the chamber when you've ejected a full/partially full mag, releasing a locked back slide before loading a magazine means there is nothing in the chamber, and being able to powerstroke pistols are but a few great details that I can think of that are so impressive and prevent you from being pulled out of the experience.

A damn solid multiplayer experience. Even without the fact its VR i would play this conventionally on a monitor.

Finally, a VR game i really want to come back to again and again, because this actually feels like a game, not the same scripted event to replay, and not an overblown tech demo.

Onward is an interesting game, it shows where the FPS genre could go when developed for VR and it certainly has a lot of expectations and opportunity that I have no doubt we will see in the coming years as VR develops. 

Onward gets you involved in a much more realistic manner to classic FPS games such as battlefield or Call of Duty, you're able to aim and fire your weapon in a very natural manner as if it were real life. You reload and charge the bolt of the rifle yourself and can change the firing modes as well and it is all very nice. You must remove the pins off grenades and then throw them which is good fun, you can even cook grenades! As someone who has fired all kinds of weapons and gone through cadetship you can really appreciate a lot of the work that went into this. 

However this is where things start going wrong. As an early accesss game it does need a lot polishing. For a start when I had to cock my weapon after a reload I would often hit my controllers together which was rather annoying and would not always allow me to charge the weapon fully. This can be... very stressful when getting shot at. I also had a lot of trouble hearing sounds when in the game, sometimes I could not tell whether someone had just stepped next to me or behind me. And it wasn't just sounds I had problems with, visual aspects of the game were quite straining to my eyesight. I don't wear glasses and have good vision, but the resolution problems with early VR access does make it hard to tell at a distance whether that object is an enemy standing still or a letterbox. 

Other issues included teamkilling. It has happened to me multiple times where a teammate may accidentally shoot me in the round or on purpose at the start. I find it frustrating that they don't seem to get punished, you can initiate a votekick but it is useless if they are playing with their friends.

These are just things I have observed with only 1.3 hours of gameplay. It certainly is a short time but overall I did not enjoy it. I do feel that this game and the fps genre have a lot of potential in VR, but that potential is yet to be realised in this game. Right now I cannot recommend this game, especially when, at the time of writing this, it costs almost £20. I do not believe the experience I gained from this game was worth it which is why I asked for a refund and do not recommend this game.

IF YOU HAVE OCULUS TOUCH READ THIS REVIEW 

This game is amazing. Even in its pre prelease state it is immersive and a ton of fun. But you will not have the most fun unless you configure your rift to let you play in 360 degrees. 
At first I thought that was going to mean buying a third sensor, which I might do still. But to be clear 2 sensors work great for me in a pretty small space. I have tried every possible configuration for the two sensors and this is what works best for me.

Step one- Place one sensor in front of you and the othor behind you. Have about 6-8 ft between the sensors. (you can do this diagonally so you arent placing a sensor in front of your monitor.)

Step two- Set the sensors higher than a desk. I have both of mine set up at about 5 1/2 ft above the floor.

Step three- Run through the Steam vr Standing room setup. Make sure the floor spacing is accurate. I usually have to input an extra 12 inches even though my oculus is sitting on the ground. 

Step four- TEST IN THE GUN RANGE. Dont jump into a game right away. Go to a single player gun range and test things out. If things arent tracking correctly you can adjust your sensors pointing them higher or lower in real time. Make it so you can spin in a cirle while aiming down your sights with no issues. Try spin in the circle again crouched. If both dont work seamlessly. You probably need to point a sensor higher or lower.  Check to make sure that the floor is in the right area. If it is too high, the game will assume you are always crouching, and you wont be able to sprint in game. You will get MURDERED. 

Step five- If you adjusted the sensors or notice that the floor was incorrectly placed run through the Steam vr standing room set up one more time.'

Step six- Test everything again in the gun range. If all is well, enjoy playing the game in a superior way!

Ich verfasse ein Review, da Onward ein sehr gutes Spiel ist.
Obwohl ich sowas wie Counterstrike und Battlefield nur selten gespielt habe, hatte ich durch den Trailer den Eindruck, dass Onward viel Potential hat. Durch einige Kommentare hatte ich allerdings den Eindruck, dass das Spiel anfängerunfreundlich sei. Dies ist falsch. In der Summe empfehle ich das Spiel also weiter.


Nach 1h gameplay:
Contras:
- Gewöhnungsbedürftiges Handling (nur am Anfang)
- Gefahr für Motionsickness 
- Man braucht Knieschoner :D

Pro:
- Sehr hohe Immersion (Es schockiert schon, wenn ein Teammate vor deinen Augen erschossen wird!)
- Verschiedene "Klassen" mit sehr viel individueller Anpassungsmöglichkeiten (Die ich in 1h gameplay nicht ausschöpfen konnte)
- Kurze knackige Runden (max. 5 min), sodass man nicht allzu lange in der Lobby rumhängen muss
- Nachdem man sich an Handling gewöhnt hat (ca. 30 min), plausibles und zielführendes Handling
- Extrem nette Community 

Beschreibung einer Runde:
Zuerst wählt man ein Team und das Equipment. Anschließend wartet man, bis alle Teammates gewählt haben (< 1min). Eine Runde dauerte (bei mir) immer zwischen 1-5 Minuten. 28249310.review:
Que dire mis à part que c'est aujourd'hui la référence en matiére d'immersion VR!

Le jeu est un 4 vs 4 dans 7 maps (pour le moment mais d'autres viendront) à l'objectif simple attaque/défense d'un point (un satellite à "hacker" en rentrant un code depuis sa tablette en étant juste à coté). Cela donne un coté dynamique aux parties étant donné qu'en fonction du camp, on est amené à élaborer des stratégies differentes. Les parties sont assez rapides et un systéme de communication par radio (main gauche sur l'épaule et appuie sur la gachette) rend le tout très immersif. 

Les controles, même s'ils ne sont pas évident aux premiers abords, sont intuitifs et assez réalistes.
-On attrape l'arme que l'on porte sur soit, la porte à une ou deux mains (qui aide à la stabilité et à la réduction du recul), on recharge en maintenant une touche et en retirant le chargeur avec l'autre main. Le fait de recharger son arme manuellement apporte une complexité au gameplay bienvenue; ça évite de se retrouver à rusher en face de 4 ennemis sans se soucier du chargeur vide.
-Les déplacements peuvent paraitre déroutant mais au final c'est la meilleure alternative pour apporter encore une fois du réalisme. Ici on ne se déplace pas en se téléportant mais bien en marchant/courant à l'aide du trackpad.
-La visée est assez complexe à longue distance malheureusement à cause du hardware du casque (le Vive dans mon cas) de part la "grille de pixel" qui se fait ressentir quand on fixe un ennemi lointain.

Les armes sont fidélement réalisées et chaque nouvelle arme utilisée apporte son petit effet de contemplation. Elles sont puissantes et trés létales. Ici on se rapproche vraiment plus de la simulation à la ARMA plutot qu'à l'arcade de Call Of. Pas besoin de vider sont chargeur pour abattre un adversaire. Les graphismes sont propres, les maps bien construites, l'univers sonore est immersif (les voix qui sont persceptible plus ou moins en fonction de la distance avec de l'echo dans la station de metro par exemple, le son des armes qui claque, notre equipement "bruyant" quand on est immobile et que l'on tourne la tête). Je n'ai pas rencontré de lags avec ma config actuelle (i7 6700k, 16go de RAM, GTX 1080 OC) mais le jeu reste assez gourmand et les CG plaus anciennes (GTX 970 ou inferieur) souffrent quelque peu.

Dernier point important, la communauté rencontrée jusqu'à présent (pas beaucoup de français pour le moment) est solide. Les joueurs sont sérieux (peu de campeurs croisés) et aident les petits nouveaux à comprendre le gameplay.

Conclusion, un trés bon jeu avec un bel avenir devant lui si les developpeurs continuent à suivre et optimiser leur produit.
A acheter sans hésiter si on aime les FPS simulation!!
