Après environs 60 heures de jeux, je me décide à poster une review. Que dire si ce n'est qu'Onward est pour moi le meilleurs jeux VR que j'ai pu testé dans sa catégorie (c'est à dire FPS en PvP). C'est bien la première fois que je ne regrette pas l'achat d'un jeu en early access. Onward est le genre de jeu dans lequel cela fait 4 parties que tu en es à ta dernière partie. Le jeu propose un gameplay dans lequel l'esprit d'équipe et la communications sont primordiales. Dans ce jeu, n’espérez pas courir à découvert avec un fusils d’assaut en mode full auto et rester en vie longtemps.

Les + :
 - Une bonne dose d'adrénaline.
 - Un jeu assez exigeant (dans le bon sens du terme). Il m'a fallut plus de 2 heure pour faire mon premier kill.
 - Des armes très réaliste avec une bonne maniabilité.
 - La santé ne se régénère pas d'elle même. Un balle ou deux suffise à mourir. (Il y a tout de même la possibilité de se soigner ou de réanimer un coéquipier à terre grâce à une seringue)
 - Le système de communication est plutôt bien foutu, et même assez intuitif: les personnes à proximité nous entendent comme IRL, et une radio est à disposition pour communiquer avec le reste de l'équipe.
 - Le mode de déplacement est plutôt bon (Pas de téléportation). J'avais un peu peur du motion-sickness au début, mais il n'en est rien. Je joue généralement plusieurs heures sans aucun soucis.
 - Pas de HUD qui casserait l'immersion. Par exemple, il n'y a pas d'indication sur le nombre de balles restant dans le chargeur, ce qui oblige à compter ses balles si on veux savoir à quel moment recharger.
 - Les tirs de suppressions sont assez bien fichu. On sent une réel pression lorsqu'on les subit.
 - Une bonne communauté dans l'ensemble, même si de temps à autre on tombe sur petit rigolo qui s'amuse à descendre toute sa team en début de partie (Ça reste heureusement marginal, et ce genre de personnes sont très vite quické). 
 - De plus en plus de Français (on croise aussi pas mal d'anglais, américain et allemand, ... donc la langue principalement parlé est l'anglais).
 - Peu importe à quelle heure de jour ou de la nuit vous souhaitez jouer, vous trouverez toujours un serveur disponible. En revanche, je pense qu'il y a encore trop peu de joueur puisqu'en moyenne il y a 6 - 8 serveur de 8 joueurs ouverts, soit moins de 64 joueurs sur l'ensemble du globe. Donc surtout n’hésitez pas à venir enrichir cette communauté.

Les  - :

 - Trop peu de maps pour le moment, mais la création de map devrait être ouverte à la communauté sous peu.
 - Un seul mode de jeu, mais d'autres sont prévu, donc "wait and see..."
 - Encore pas mal de petits bugs (écran noir, tableau des scores qui pète un plomb, joueurs bloqué au spawn, passer à travers le sol et atterrir sous la map). Heureusement, on ne rencontre ces bugs que assez rarement. On les pardonnera d’ailleurs pour le moment étant donné que le jeu est encore early access.
 - Une prise en main un peu difficile au début (d'autant plus qu'il n'y a pas de vrai tuto à ce jour), mais une fois l'étape d'apprentissage passé, c'est un vrai plaisir.
 - Quelques soucis d'optimisation. On peut constater quelques baisses de framerate dans certaines zones de certaines cartes. Le jeu tourne néanmoins plutôt bien en règle général.
 - Le fait d'avoir en main des manettes, et non réellement une arme (donc pas de poids, pas de crosse...) fait un peu perdre en stabilité en donc en précision. Il est tout de même possible de se fabriquer un support pour les manettes avec des tubes en PVC et un peu d'imagination.
 - Encore quelques grillages à l'épreuve des balles.
 - Pas de possibilité de grimper au échelles ou de franchir un obstacle pas plus haut qu'une table. Il semble toute fois que cette fonctionnalité soit prévu dans un future plus ou moins proche.
 - La résolution du vive encore trop faible rend assez la distinction des joueurs au loin assez difficile. (même si la je chipote un peu, ce n'est pas vraiment un problème inhérent au jeu)


 En résumé : Un excellent jeu très immersif et assez exigent. Encore beaucoup de possibilité d'amélioration en terme de fonctionnalité et de contenu et quelques bugs bloquant survienne de temps à autre. Ce jeu à un énorme potentiel. Je le recommande vivement, même en early access.

I'm no more than two hours into the game currently. BUT! That's in one session. This game is fantastic. I've only stopped to wait for my animals to shut the f*** up so I don't annoy my mates in-game. So the informal, early review; 

     Onward is a first person shooter in VR form, akin to Counter Strike or ARMA, as silly as that sounds. It's a mil-sim (Military Simulator, not to insult anyone's intelligence) and it doesn't really fail at that, however, it plays out more like a simplified version of R6 Siege. You are pitted with seven other players in a map that the eight of you vote over. The teams, as expected, are divided into two, 4 on each squad. In itself, none of this sounds special. However, with this overused method applied to the Vive, this makes this game the most appreciated purchase I have made on the Vive, contending with maybe Audioshield. 
     You move about in your roomscale play area for the cover use and corridor maneuvering but the real movement takes place on the trackpad, being utilized as more of an analog stick. At first, I didn't like this method. It had been used in a horror game I tried a while back but it seemed cheap. Now, I'm thinking maybe it was the game and not the locomotion. In this game, this mode of walking seems intuitive and works out well enough, until we get our omnidirectional treadmills. (You'd better be working on it, HTC...or whoever else Valve commisions) This seems to simply be the best way to avoid that break in immersion as of right now, unless you're A Chair In A Room and you can get away with just being a set of finite areas.
     TL;DR this game is worth your money. Yes the pricetag is highish for a Vive game right now but to be fair, most games are tech demos, essentially, for the Vive. This game isn't that. It is in early access but so much has been done to it now that it no longer feels like it. I can't spout the usual "It has potential...but..." This game is just already worth it. 


   Oh, and it has a playerbase unlike some games. If I'm not mistaken, Art Of Fight isn't being heavily played, anymore. Which is saddening.

26146705.review:
This is going to be a long review.

Bugs:
Periodically when you die, the game will glitch and you will be stuck above your body. The only way out is the exit the game and re-enter. If a host creates a lobby and exits, there is no way to start the game as the host doesn't migrate to a new person. The game freezes when entering a game and shows that you are offline. Hitting "reconnect" does nothing and the game just hangs at the loading screen.

Single Player:
There is no "single player" option in the game but there is the shooting range. This mode is under the multiplayer option but plays as single player. This mode includes a rifle range in which you can demo all of the in-game weapons as well as a kill house where you can get in some target practice.

War:
This is the actual game mode. This is a 4v4 online shooter. If you are worried that there will not be anyone online, you will be surprised. There is usually an open game lobby to join. If not, create your own and people will join. In the lobby, you can chat with both teams but in the game, you can only chat with your team either through voice when close or radio over a distance. The descriptors for this game say "realistic." Don't expect that to be the case. It usually consists of throwing as many flashes as possible and stabbing the other team. There are no tactics. Also, expect to have squeakers on one of the teams running their mouth. Most of the time, no one in the lobby speaks your language.

Wanted features:
A dedicated single player mode. Language filter for the lobby since team games are hard when you don't speak the same language. Faster matchmaking. Ability to mute other players.

Overall:
Not a bad game. The controls take a bit to get used to. It can be frustrating at first but gets better as you practice and play. Overall, I would say it is a 3/5. With more polish and a single player campaign with even some workshop missions added in, this game could easily be the best combat VR game. The developers have worked hard on this game and the 3/5 I give it for an early access game is well deserved. I would highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to see what a VR shooter should be. If development continues as is, this game will be the best VR game in around a year.

Alright. So. For the first few days I was kinda upset I bought this. Like, every time I moved I was at like 10fps, I couldn't figure out the damn controls, some of the people are assholes, etc. But now I have figured out all the fixes to improve my frame rate, and figured out the controls, and now its fun.

For anyone having framerate issues:
First thing that helped was reducing the quality in unity. Sit at your computer, start steam vr, and then start Onward while holding ALT. This will bring up a settings window you cannot access from in-game. Reduce quality here (I did mine to fastest and it works swimmingly, haven't tried upping it again).

Second thing was minimizing the game window after the game starts (On the desktop). This one is a bit weird but it makes a weird kind of sense. Why make your gpu display on a headset AND a monitor huh? I don't really know why, but this helped my frame rate a bunch.

Third thing was making sure NOT to have the "Always Projecting" or whatever setting on in vive settings. Make sure it is UNCHECKED. That's the one next to direct mode (Which I keep ON always).

Okay, that's done. Now for playing the game properly:
First, google the tutorial. It's short and teaches you some important things, like reloading and where your stuff on your vest is and how to use it.
But there's one important thing it didn't teach me. If you're like me, you'll see people darting off and you're like How the fuck do you run that fast? And nobody will tell you. WELL CHILDREN IT'S ACTUALLY PRETTY SIMPLE! (Caps lock is cruise control for cool). Just start moving with the left touch pad, and then click it in once or twice. After clicking it twice (each time you start moving from a standing position) you are at top speed. This makes the game far more fun, but also more nauseating.

I hope I have helped at least one person. I like this game and will be playing it for quite some time.

Before I give my actual review, at the time of this writing I only have an hour and a half of playtime against a bunch of chinese people with chinese ping. (And I am on the west coast, USA.)

First impressions: I screwed around in the shooting range enough to figure out how to aim, reload, and throw grenades, the shooting range didn't have much in it, which gave me a bad feeling about how the game itself was going to be, but since there wasn't a lot left to mess with I jumped into a game.

My experiences:
Immediately, I realized that I didn't bring night vision because I didn't know it was a night map. I glanced over to my right to see my team mate prone-crawling on the ground with his arms above his head to shoot over cover. I lost my shit and then was instantly shot in the face.

After that mistake, I spent the next several rounds just getting used to the slide movement controls (After popping some Dramamine to avoid motion sickness because I get it easily with slide movement.), but finally after a 3 or 4 matches with 0 kills and dying every round, I managed to get my first kill. Then two more. Then I was pretty hooked. 

I played for an hour and a half straight and only stopped because of bugs/crashes, but decided to write my review while everything is fresh in my mind. So here we go!

My review:

The gameplay is solid, there's an artificial suppression mechanic in place like many FPS which does help with immersion, the shooting is alright, though there's no real feedback in the controllers which detracts from the feel of it but there's not much that can be done about that.

Controls are... alright, they definitely need work at this stage of the development. For example, you reload by pressing down (As in the bottom section) on the gun-holding hand's track pad, then hold the trigger to grab the magazine with your other hand, grab a spare magazine off your belt and then drop it in and pull the charging handle then you're set. That's fine, because this is a "mil-sim", however the problem comes when you need to pull a charging handle and end up slamming your controllers together. Or worse, you try to reach for a spare magazine but because of the direction you're looking you can't actually grab anything off of your body. This is also a huge problem when trying to grab a grenade, or your medical syringe, or anything off of your body honestly.

Weapons are decent as well, but could use some work. An example of this would be the 4x (ACOG) scope on some guns is tiny, just... it's incredibly small, the size of or smaller than the red dot sights. As well, it seems like sights are too close to your face unless you hold your arm far from your body, with sniper scopes I had to almost hold my arm out as far as I could reach for the scope to not clip through my face (That is with the one sniper I tried.).

All primary weapons have the same attachment and ammo choices, which means guns like the VAL which has an internal suppressor still has the suppressor option which does nothing, and has a foregrip attachment option that doesn't mount. The same issue is on a lot of weapons, and for example the shotgun, your ammo choices are FMJ, FMJ Tracer, and AP. Not shot or slug. These are menu options that I'm nitpicking but still.

Summary?

I enjoyed it a lot, it's a little hard to get into but a lot of fun once you do, I can't wait to see something like 8v8 matches in the future, and maybe addition weapons and attachments, as well as the improvement of the contols. Even through the bugs, there was no time where I was just frustrated or angry, I just wanted the game to restart faster so I could go back to playing.

This game is just what VR needs right now to save it from dying, it's an actual game, with actual gameplay, and I sincerely hope the devs don't give up or abandon this project.  If you're looking for a new VR game to play and you're on the fence about this due to the price tag, it's worth it as it stands. I've already gotten more play time out of it than most VR games I have and that was in just one sitting!

25712590.review:
I won't lie, I was reluctant to buy this. Despite the high praise from pretty much everyone in the VR community, I thought £18.99 was a bit steep. But I decided to bite the bullet and give it a go. I like ARMA, Insurgency and of course; Hotdogs Horseshoes and Hand Grenades, so I was pretty sure I'd be in for an enjoyable experience.

So let's get to the nitty gritty shall we?

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The other reviews don't lie, this game plays like a dream. And I had no problems of motion sickness with the game's movement system (even at sprint speed). And it's thanks to this movement system that I can say this is more non-room scale friendly than Raw Data. The guns are almost on par with Hotdogs Horseshoes and Hand Grenades, although they're much more forgiving when it comes to inserting fresh magazines into the gun. Which certainly helps in the middle of a frantic firefight.

There are plenty of servers bustling with players. Something I didn't expect from a Vive game anytime soon, so you'll always be able to find a match. What helps more is that the community is one of the nicest communities in any multiplayer game that I've played, and are always sure to make noobs (such as myself) feel welcome. The netcode is also super solid, I never had problems finding/connecting to matches. And everything during a match felt responsive and lag-free.

[b]Visuals[/b]
Much like Hotdogs Horseshoes and Hand Grenades, visuals are very much what one would expect of a Unity game, but it looks nice enough (especially the new Subway map). If I do have one minor niggle, is that the game is rather prone to performance drops on my GTX980, (but it's still playable, so it's not a big deal).

[b]Sound[/b]
"What's this Sheppy? A new sound section?" I don't normally comment on the sound design in VR games because they're all generally solid on that front. But this game requires a special mention, as the sound is absolutely stellar. And very, very loud (if you want it to be, there's "Realistic" and "Normal" sound mixes depending on how much you wanna blast your ears.) Being supressed by enemy gunfire in the heat of battle is both terrifying and exciting, and all these sounds come together to bring one of the most immersive experiences in VR to date.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
If you like military sims, ruining underwear, spouting cheesy one-liners and moderate amounts of gun porn. Then this is the VR game for you. And in time, with the [i]very[/i] regular updates that the dev is providing. This could turn into something very special for VR.

I play a lot of vr, at least a few different games a day. I'm a huge VR fan in general and am hoping beyond hope that it'll survive as a platform (or "peripheral" for those of you that want to get super technical on word usage... trolls). So, I'm not going to diss on other games or vr in general to prove how good Onward is. Having said that, Onward is a very good game. It does what most good games do. It gives players toys (military toys in this case) and a multiplayer sandbox to use those toys in. What VR adds that no other game-to-date can is that elusive "presence". This game has presence in spades. OK, maybe not at first as the movement system is a little jarring and can cause motion sickness (you get used to it if you give it some time) . The learning curve is also a tad steep, but when you are the last person alive and the comms have gone dead, is when Onward really shines.

You'll remind yourself to stay in control to keep your heart from pounding out of your chest, to keep your hands steady and true, and your eyes wide open. You'll try and remind yourself it is only a game, but the perspiration will start to creep in as reality fades away, you'll hold your breath, your hands will tremble. You will feel alone and afraid. You'll wait, listen, look for any sign that'll give an advantage and a chance to snag the round. Time will slow and then, in a coming-to-an-epiphany-sorta-way, something will happen, something that I imagine can happen in the real world too. A confidence will start to fill in your veins as you'll imagine yourself as a victorious hero walking into a room, pistol in hand, and squeezing off four precise headshots to win in an epic, merciless fashion. You'll imagine placing each shot though your opponents skull like a skilled surgeon prescribing each bullet to its victim. "One for you, you, you and one for you", you'll say to yourself as blood flies and bodies fall.

The adrenaline that first caused fear turns to fight, and off you go as a one man team with a grand idea against an unknown number of enemies, weapon in hand and loaded for bear. You'll creep, crawl, run, stop, listen, look and repeat. You'll clear rooms. You'll peek around corners then pull your head back only to peek again. You'll push on, but most importantly, you will face your fate. You will face your enemy with a steady hand and determination as sharp as a razor's edge, and there he is! You see him, but did he see you? You hold your breath. You look again. Oh s*it! He saw you. A realization of now-or-never grips you.... fight or flight. You pay no attention to the fact there may be more than the one. You need this kill. Around the corner you go, out from cover, gun ready, gun aimed... BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG, you let the bullets fly. POP, POP, POP, POP, he fires back. Without thinking you head back to cover. The screen dims, you've been shot, but it's not fatal. You need healing. You reach for the syringe and stop... there's no time. A voice playing like a broken record way down under the intensity comes to your conscious state. "Reload, Reload!!!", it is saying. "f*ck", you respond and do as the voice commands. You reload like a well oiled machine, accurately, quickly, desperately. Then, while pulling back the bolt and barely giving it a chance to close, out of cover you fly again... BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG... The real world melts into a distant past and blurs into obscurity as all you have now is your instinct to survive and your weapon to survive behind. For victory or for defeat, for life or for death. You go... Onward.

That is what makes this game great. For that moment, it is REAL to you, you are there. Explaining that feeling is like trying to explain love. It can only be had by doing, by feeling. That is presence. That is the potential of VR. That is what this game can do.

25495847.review:
I would like to say here that this is the first review I've written for a game. :D

First off, this game is clearly in Early Access. It has bugs. Don't be surprised, but don't let that stop you from playing the best VR FPS game there is.

Onward is a first person shooting military simulator. I know Steam said exactly that above so I'll specify a bit. Onward has accurate firing. You must aim appropriately and match the sight on your target. Firing takes careful aim or you will miss. There is no quick scoping or killing someone accross the map unless you have a sniper rifle (Even though aiming with those is pretty difficult). There are no menus to choose your sidearm or attachments. There is no "VR Teleporting". There are no hit markers and there is no confirmation of kills. You have to confirm yourself.


The game has two lobbys: Shooting range and War.

In Shooting range you can practice your accuracy with the weapons within the game. 8 people can join you in the shooting range as well. There are targets at close, medium, and long ranges. There is also a simulation corner of the range that lets you practice close quarters firing. It helps to let you get used to the movement of checking corners. The only issue I have with the shooting range is that the shots you make on the targets are faint and they disappear before you can even get to the target, but that's just a tiny pet peeve. 

After you've practiced in the shooting range you can play the primary part of the game called War.

In War, you can choose between two teams Volk and MARSOC. Each team can have a max of 4 players, 8 players total. You choose from a list of classes which are Rifleman, Specialist, Automatic Rifleman and Marksman. Each class has weapons that coincide with that class. The Marksman has bolt action rifles with 12x range scopes for example. You can customize the weapon such as the sight, barrel, and ammo. Oh, also each team has selected chosen weapons that you won't find on the other team.
You can then choose your sidearm pistol, types of grenades, and additonal gear such as an extra morphine syringe (You use the syringe to give yourself more health or revive a teammate before they bleed out), night vision goggles, and body armor. My only complaint about the loadout screen is I wish there are explanations for each item for people who are not miltary savvy, but its a mil sim so to be expected.

I believe there are 4 maps so far. 3 of these maps have a night version to play and the 4th is always at night.

Once in the game you are placed at opposite ends of the map, one team defending and another attacking. The attacking team have codes to enter into the objective to win. If a team is completely wiped out the opposing team wins.

The movement is a little clunky, but you quickly forget that once you get into the game. If you kneel in real life, you kneel in the game. If you go prone (Lie flat on your stomach) in real life you go prone in the game.
You control your movement with the touch pad on the Vive controller. Your default setting is to walk, but you can run by double clicking the touch pad on the controller. If you put your weapon away and you have free hands you move faster. 

Every piece of gear you have is available on your VR body and you have to manually find it on your person and grab it to use it. To help with grabbing gear off your chest there is a slight vibration in the controller to tell you you're in the right spot to grab a piece of gear off your body. The knife is on your left shoulder, the radio is near your left ear, the map is near the right side of your back on the waist etc. 

For communication you must be in proximity or using the radio system. Communication is essential in Onward. Friendly fire happens all the time and the only way to prevent that is communicating.

Onward is the one VR game that I have been consistently coming back to play. The feeling of working as a unit to accomplish the goal or getting that first contact down with your vive controllers is so much fun.

Sorry for rambling on! Hope this helps give you a good idea of Onward!

25490236.review:
This is the best Vive experience I've had. While I did enjoy the likes of Hover Junkers and even the silly Job Simulator, the only game that had kept my interest was Hotdogs, Horseshoes, and Hand Grenades. Now that I've played Onward, I can finally say that VR has a game worthy of the asking price of the Vive itself. 

Everything in this game is intuitive, looks great, and sounds great. The only minor problem I've had with the controls is working things on the guns (accidentally hitting both controllers together repeatedly while trying to pull back the bolt, for example). Aside from that, the game plays exactly as expected. THANK GOD FOR TRACKPAD MOVEMENT! I was starting to get worried that devs were going to completely abandon that type of movement due to complaints of motion sickness. Spend a few minutes with it, and it feels natural. 

The game does have a lack of maps, but the few maps that are there are mostly great. The only one I didn't particularly enjoy was the Tanker, due to it being so cramped, which made for easy early game grenade kills. After a few more are added, and the currently existing ones are polished, this won't be a con at all. Dynamic weather could be a game changer if it's added as well. 

The game does have a stuttering problem every now and then. One screen will flicker and the game will run pretty slowly, but it only lasts for half a minute at most, then it's back to normal. This will probably be fixed in an update.

Overall, Onward is a huge step forward for VR as a whole. Once PSVR hits the market, I'm sure development of longer games is going to skyrocket, but for now, Onward is king for me (though I haven't had the chance to play Raw Data yet). 

Also, VR hugs.

When I first saw the videos on DevilDogGamers channel, I knew that this was going to be big. The first realistic multiplayer military style shooter for VR is now here. I did not know untill tonight that it would be releasing today and I decided to stay up untill midnight to buy it, if the price is reasonable of course.

At first I thought the price was fair, but after the first hour into the game I am suprised this didnt cost over $30. This game has plenty of guns, attachments, gear, accesories, etc. that I did not expect for a brand new early access game. The gameplay is pretty stellar but I would change a few things.

It does not come without some problems though. The map/objective tablet is pretty difficult to get out because we cant see where we need our hand to be. Some of the buildings in the game are poorly designed and have pointless rooms, but it's not too bad. There are some holes in the floor of the map on the map with the crashed helicopter. The inventory system is kinda finicky. And the objective is extremely hard to play, easy to defend, and hard to find.
But what this game gets right, it gets right. The locomotion in my experience has had no effect whatsoever on me, but I have heard other experiences of motion sickness from other people, but for me it's cake. Being able to look around while running is incredibly natural and kind of feels like I'm riding a bike and the Vive wand is my handlebar. The radio works so well and it feels so cool to use. The models of the characters look and move quite naturally with the movement of the player, the arms seem mapped quite well. The sounds of the guns are amazing and on the realistic setting is quite scary the first time you hear gunfire whizzing by your head.

The social interaction is also definitely a lot of fun, but I can see plenty of room for people to grief and troll by killing teammates on purpose because as far as I know, there is no penalty for team killing. I am sure a system for that will come later but for now the people I played with were people who were also looking to play a fun game of war.
This is definitely one of my favorite VR purchases right up there with Raw Data and Audio Shield. Looking foward to many more hours in this new world of Onward.

25372423.review:
Welcome to the future.

This is it. On a rooftop, last man of my team remaining... at least nobody was answering the radio calls anymore. Enemy team is using smoke to approach the objective, I spray the AK with just my arms over the wall and in that general direction, can't say if I've hit something but now I'm empty and must reload. Empty mag out, new mag in. Peek over the wall again. There they are, two brown clothed soldiers going right. Line up the first, remembering to look to the center of the display to get a clearer image. Fire! No fire? Damnit! Forgot to pull back the charging handle... come on, come on! Pull myself up again over the short wall... where did they go? Bang, I'm dead.

Being an avid simmer and a fan of immersion I've waited for VR for a long, long time. But when I finally managed to buy a Vive (thank you HTC+Valve for excluding Portugal :-P), one category of games was missing: a realistic FPS.

That wait is over! Onward is not only a realistic FPS, it's the most realistic FPS ever. No HUD. In fact, there is no info on your VR display except what you would see in reality... your hands, your gun and whatever else you are carrying, like the tablet with the GPS map. Sound is amazing and adds a lot, especially if you choose the deafening realistic option.

Weapon handling looks real although sometimes you can fumble it up and hit both controllers over and over trying to pull a bolt back. Communications are important in-game and the proximity VoIP in conjunction with the fantastically thought out shoulder click radios cover all needs. Suppression is well balanced and the need to inject yourself or others when injured is very well done. 

I was really surprised with the movement feature. Besides teleporting I had only tried moving in another game (The Solus Project) and had trouble with balancing. In Onward it's perfect, no balance problems, no nausea (didn't have it on other games anyway), I suspect the movement acceleration is more progressive and that helps.

At the time of writing this review, the game is still buggy, and performance is lacking (GTX970, low settings) for what are very basic graphics. But even in Early Access you can see that the base game is there, it's foundations are very strong, gameplay and idea wise, it just needs to be built on technically.

And don't forget to chamber the round if needed. Need to crouch? So do it. Want to stabilize your aim and give a minimal target? Don't be shy to lie on the floor. 

The gameplay itself is still rudimentary. 2 modes, 4 maps. The graphics are unpolished but very usable. It's the first of its kind on the first iteration of the hardware. The sound is suprisingly well done and very important in the game. Multiplayer has a lot more players atm than Hover Junkers for example. Waiting times are minimal (GMT +1, Sat evening experiencce). 

Despite the pre-VR movement controls and lack of teleport there is no motion sickness. Somehow the devs pulled it off. After a few minutes you adjust to movement via the trackpad of your off hand. There are still some glitches while moving over obstables and such but it works brilliantly for the most part. 

All in all Onward is the best FPS shooter experience you can have in VR right now. And it really makes me long for its successor on the next generation of hardware - because then I won't play anything else anymore.

If you want an ArmA or Rainbow 6 experience in VR look no further. While it is currently a bit glitchy and rough around the edges (especially in the GUI), no other game has come close to this level of tactical, skill-based immersion. Guns feel real, movement is handled like a dream, and the radio chatter element rocks.

A couple notes:
- Take your time in the shooting range with different guns. Far too often I'd wait in lobby and launch into a match with a gun I've never used thinking I'd just "figure it out". I ended up switching to pistol instead.
- If you have a friend to play with, join a shooting range lobby with them and mess around. This is a great way to learn the game and have a blast. You can even practice sniping at each other, knifing, or have a quick draw! If you have no friends, join a random range lobby and there is sure to be someone willing to show you the ropes "in person". The wait to get into a regular match is a bit draining, especially for your first day in as you will die quick and be forced to watch. This is why I recommend the shooting range for your first time in.

For those worried about motion sickness, what worked for me was:
     1) Squinting my eyes when walking up hills, rocks or uneven surfaces.
     2) Remaining still while using the touchpad movement. As in, don't walk backwards in room-scale as you're walking forward.
     3) Bob your head up and down when sprinting.

25298953.review:
tl;dr - Buy this game if you are willing to deal with a few hiccups (nothing quite game breaking anymore) in order to experience what the beginning of the future holds for FPS games. You'll walk away with watercooler moments every day you play. 

This is an awesome step for VR. Highly addictive gameplay is an understatement. I can't wait to see where this winds up - I really hope it doesn't become some speed shooter. The competition and the incredible community just keep on giving. Everyone online so far with the exception of 2 players I've played with has been incredibly helpful and very enjoyable to play with. I hope this type of community continues and grows, because so far it's awesome to make friends in. If you buy this game do yourself a favor and STAY IN THE SERVERS. If you hop around when you die sure you'll get into the action again faster but you definitely won't build up any relationships and experience half the awesome things I have playing this game.  

The addition of player controlled analog motion (which honestly isn't THAT much different than Hover Junkers) is very well done and doesn't bother me motion sickness wise. You may get dizzy doing things a little crazy like clearing stairways or something, but it doesn't last. A game like this really couldn't be played with teleportation so I'm VERY thankful that this is done so well. 

There is a wide variety of weapons and they all handle very well if a bit similar in feel. They're just slightly less fancy and more simplified than H3VR. Reloading is NOT the big deal that a lot of people complain about and there is a tutorial video that shows how to do everything on youtube. This isn't COD or any other game where you just press the button and the animation plays. Reloading isn't supposed to just happen without a little practice and fumbling at first in real life, so why should it be different in VR? Once you know what to do, it's all easily accomplished and feels awesome in the heat of being suppressed. 

As for performance - yeah it's got bugs. No surprise. You WON't be getting away with supersampling unless you love reprojection, but I've been doing ok without it. If you are running stock settings, and have a decent gpu (970/980/ti) you should easily get very constant 90fps at default settings. At 1.5+ with a 980ti I was at nearly constant reprojection which I didn't enjoy so I'm just settling for stock. Grabbing items from your vest at first can be a little frustrating because it seems the vest clips through the environment which occludes you from grabbing equipment. This only is a problem for going prone or crouching your entire body over rather than just sitting down with a straight back. Straighten up and you can get everything pretty easy. You just learn to do it after a couple close calls.

This IS the game that we have all been waiting for for VR. Yes it is an alpha, so bugs are to be expected. But for what it is currently, it's AMAZING. $24 bucks is sooooooo worth it, and the community for the game has been great as well. For anyone having issues with the mono.dll files though, ill post a fix i found for it here as well:

If you downloaded the game and had this mono.dll issue, here's what i did:

-Uninstall the game
-Clear your anti-virus vault/quarantine zone (where it put the mono.dll file)
-Redownload the game, DO NOT LAUNCH IT
-Go to your anti-virus and manually add an exception for the mono.dll file to go through your firewall(mine was D:\Steam\SteamApps\common\Onward\Onward_Data\Mono\mono.dll)
-Game should launch

For another temporary fix that i had a friend do, repeat the first 3 steps above, but instead of adding anything to your firewall, just disable the firewall before you launch them game and enable it again once the game has successfully launched.

Hope this helps someone!

Je suis un passionné de VR, je regardais toutes les news depuis au moins 2 ans sur tous les produits VR, j'ai Acheté le VIVE en Juillet, et ai joué à une douzaine de jeux VR et bien ...

CELUI LA EST JUSTE LE MEILLEUR. Pour un jeu en accès anticipé, il est tout à fait correct (ATTENTION LES DEVELOPPEURS JE NE VOUS ENCOURAGE PAS A LAISSER LE PRODUIT A SON ETAT ACTUEL, AU CONTRAIRE !! ^^)

La façon de se déplacer est fluide au trackpad (pas de téléportation !! WAHOUUUU ENFIN !!), elle pourrait peut-être donner des maux de crane à certain, moi ça ne m'a rien fait en tout cas. 

D'ailleurs, je trouve que c'est la meilleure façon pour garder un maximum d'immersion. RAW DATA qui est un des meilleurs jeux auxquels j'ai joué en VR à ce défaut de ne laisser le joueur se déplacer uniquement par la téléportation. on a l'impression de se retrouver dans un point'n click ...

LES + :
-immersion
-sens de l'équipe
-prise en compte des positions du joueur (couché, assis, debout)
-les armes, le rechargement, la personnalisation
-les maps
-le hud inexistant : on ne sait pas si on tire sur un ami ou un ennemi, si on l'a touché, s'il est mort, combien de personnes il reste... comme en vrai quoi
-le stress provoqué comme dans une partie d'airsoft (ou presque)
-les PV des joueurs réaliste (pas à la HALO ^^)

LES-:
-pas de tutoriel ??? heureusement qu'il y a les collègues pour nous dire comment faire XD
-le son des coups de feu pas très bien gérés (on ne sait pas d'où ils viennent eux par contre)
-les graphismes ? bon je chipote, si c'était plus joli qu'un counter strike, ma machine ne suivrait pas
-pas assez de settings et pas possible de les changer en pleine partie.
-la possibilité pour l'admin de lancer une partie sans tous les joueurs de "ready" et de ce fait, faire attendre les joueurs qui n'étaient pas prêt pour pouvoir jouer, toute une partie.

Bon comme il n'y a pas de tutos, j'en fait un :

1) on peut discuter avec son équipe :
- s'ils sont près, pas besoin de faire quoi que ce soit, la direction et le volume du son des joueurs sont très bien gérés puisqu'il nous permet d'estimer leur position.
- dès qu'ils s'éloignent, on peut utiliser la radio (mettre la main libre sur l'épaule gauche et tenir la gâchette tout au long de la discussion comme au talky-walky)

2) lacher/reprendre son arme : soit le grip soit un autre bouton (vous avez le choix dans les settings)

3) recharger : 
- restez appuyé sur le bas du trackpad de la main qui tient l'arme
- et avec la main libre attraper le chargeur à enlever avec la gâchette, lacher le chargeur vide
- attrapez un nouveau chargeur sur votre gilet avec la gachette(ou le grip je ne sais plus) de la main libre
- approchez le de l'emplacement du chargeur dans l'arme, jusqu'au "clic" et lacher tous les boutons

4)soigner quelqu'un :
- lâcher son arme avec le bouton que vous avez choisi dans les settings
- approcher la main principale de la seringue en bas de son gilet
- attraper la seringue et l'approcher du blessé
- appuyer simultanément sur le trackpad et la gâchette de la main qui tient la seringue pour soigner le blessé

5)mettre la vision de nuit :
- choisir la vision de nuit dans l'équipement avant la partie (là où il y a le gilet pare-balle)
- dans la partie, mettre la main libre proche de votre oreille et appuyer sur la gâchette


Voilà c'est les principaux trucs pour lesquels j'ai dû demander, allez tcho ;)

[h1][b]缺點：[/b][/h1]
▼優化不佳
畫面流暢度無法穩定保持60~90fps以上，并且游戲本身bug還是算蠻多的，不過在搶先體驗版本中這個能夠理解，并不會太影響游戲性。

▼沒有新手教學
游戲本身是非常Hardcore的，而沒有新手教學這點會讓剛上手的玩家非常頭痛，不過摸索也是一種享受游戲的過程。

▼死亡機制不佳
被打死還好，能直接回到大廳觀戰。
但是如果你瀕死的話...你只能黑白地看著你的角色在地上掙扎，等待隊友救援，有時候會等很久，不耐煩。
同時也建議在大廳裝設靶場，讓等待的人也能好好練練槍法，不會那麽無聊。

▼控制器的判定不佳
游戲中各種槍支的操作都較爲複雜，并且範圍判定非常嚴格。而在戰場上你往往會需要快速地換彈夾，在這過程中兩個搖桿很容易會撞在一起，進而影響到游戲中的操作。
希望判定能較爲寬鬆，或根據Vive控制器來調整槍支操作範圍，不然Vive控制器很快就被我敲壞了...

▼拿取的判定不佳
主武器、手榴彈、手槍、醫療針筒等物品都是直接一堆放在身上，很常發生要換手槍或拿手榴彈的時候拿不到而被殺的事情，建議將物品間的距離拉長，或增强拿取的判定範圍。

▼單場人數過少
目前最高單場人數是 4 vs. 4，但跟龐大的地圖比起來人數真的有點太少了，互相找不到人、躲貓貓的情形太多了，希望能增加人數限制，或者加入PvE反恐行動之類的模式來與朋友享受合作的樂趣。

[h1][b]整體評分：[/b][/h1]
[i]9.5/10[/i] 
[h1][b]極度推薦！[/b][/h1][b]樂趣與潛力無限的游戲，但還是有進步空間！[/b]



這是我給過VR游戲中的最高分數，與Raw Data同分。
老實説看到預告的時候我以爲這是一款很無趣的軍事游戲，但實際自己開始玩的時候才發現這款游戲真的非常不一樣！
喜歡第一人稱射擊、CS:GO的VR玩家們，一定要來試試看，他可以説是第一款做到了讓你直接進入軍事戰場廝殺與求生的游戲，大推！

The devs are right to say that, "Onward is still in it's infancy..."  The game is by no means polished, by no means does it have stunning graphics, nor by any means is it optimized for average VR PC builds.  It's really the little things that start to add up together that make you question what the devs were thinking when they slapped this jalopy of a game together.  A myriad of bugs make the game, at times, unplayable, and often make it difficult to focus on the core of the game.  

However.  It doesn't change the facts.

What Dante and the Downpour devs have strung together, albeit with some hairy, fraying string, is a truly incredible game.  The underlying concepts are all there, and they shine through the bugs and design mistakes, making me want to come back to this game continuously and spend all my time in it despite the numerous hiccups.  The best part is that it's this good at day 1 of the Alpha.  It only gets better from here.

I have actual PTSD from virtual war.  Friends I just got to know, talking side by side, laughing about how we all store our war PDAs up our arses (you really have to reach to get the damn thing out) vaporized in the sound-barrier cracklings of bullets hurtling through their flesh.  I am alone, crawling on the actual ground, fighting in actual shock with enemies closing in from god-knows-where, and I run away from the scene, still shocked, vengeance the only concept that can grow in my emotionless new world.  Then I halt, scream, and die.  

Drama aside, I thought I was immune to VR causing any kind of psychophysical response within me after developing for the HTC Vive since January.  Wrong.  Buy this game, get an experience that would, had you otherwise attained it, cost your life.  

With mixed feelings, I will say that in my opinion, this is the best game currently sold for the Vive.  This is a 'killer app' with mediocre implementation, and yet it easily shines to the top.  I am happy and excited about what can be done in VR from here on out, and I'm quite well anticipating future updates to this game; yet I feel melancholy that within the year or so that devs that got 'face time' with the press and Valve had time to develop, nothing of this calibre has come.

Onward is my absolute favourite game for the Vive to date. It is the one and only game that has kept me glued to my Vive. When I first got my Vive I was basically glued to it, but there hasn't been another game that has kept me playing one specific game exclusively like this one. Alot of people say when they got their Vives they were  never going back to normal monitor games. I, on the otherhand still loved to play ARMA3 and RainbowSix Siege. Although now since this game has come out I don't know if there is enough time in the day to play anything else lol. I would call it a Must Buy! for anyone who enjoys Milsim games and owns a vive.
  
                                          GENERAL

   I find Onward compares pretty closely to a game like Insurgency, but with slightly slower pacing.Some people think the game is so slow its boring, but that is only the case if you don't know how to play or you are playing with other that don't get it too. The maps are decently big which provides space to make manouvers, but you are always attacling a specific point in the map. As long as the players in the game understand that, you get great action packed matches. There are a few bugs that have caused me to have to restart the game on occasion. This circumstance is very rare though, about 1 in 10 games at the most for me. It however has not taken away from my enjoyment of this title one bit. It is one of the most intense and exciting MilSim games I have ever had the chance to play. Teamwork is key, and Onward has provided some of the best teamplay I have seen in a game. When your moving around a corner either whispering or using hand signals as to not alert an enemy because you know he is very close it's just great. Other great moments come from spotting someone at a great distance and stepping back behind cover to radio and make sure it's not a friendly.
   
                                           MECHANICS
  
    I am also very impressed with the amount of guns, attachments, grenades and the other things available in the loadouts. The weapon mechanics are also great, akin to H3VR if you've played it. Using these realistic weapon mechanics in an intense firefight makes all the difference. The mechanics of the game make it a truly skill and teamwork based game that is exciting to play. It you don't master your weapon mechanics and radio usage you are going to have a hell of a time in this game.

                                           COMMUNITY
   
  So far at this early stage of the game I have found nothing but awesome people to play with. Everyone is talking and communicating to get things done. Those that don't know what they are doing yet have all showed a willingness to learn and hear people out. Overally its the best experience I have had with people in the vive and I hope it keeps on heading in the same direction.

There are both large day maps and close quarters night maps, and they all play differently. It's purely PvP at the moment, there are no bot modes (but plenty of people online).

All communication is done through in game voice chat, which works fantastically (the enemy can hear you if you're talking to loudly, so be careful!). There are a variety of different role types and weapons to suit team comp and personal preference, the the role types are restricted (so you can't have an entire team of snipers :D ).


It also has great locomotion controls that are *slightly* more sickening than teleporting, but I had no problems with them even after a few hours of play. The grip and weapon controls are also very intuitive, although the game does thrust quite a few options upon you at first launch - a tutorial would be nice. There are some performance issues here and there, and definitely a lot of rough edges, but overall this is a must have game for any Vive owner and I can't recommend it enough, it's really good fun.

(EDITED ON 12-09-16)

I was really anticipating this game and wasn't disappointed. The dev seemed to put a lot of time into game testing and feedback before putting it into early access, and it REALLY shows.

After watching the recommended tutorial and practicing on the in-game shooting range, I tried out multiplayer. And it was awesome!
When I got my Vive it was to play horror games and FPS shooters. And so far there had been no "realistic" shooter in the same style as ARMA for VR. Until now that is.
If you like slower paced ARMA styled military sim games, then you will instantly love this title.

GRAPHICS AND SOUND
For a Vive game it is one of the better looking action type games when it comes to the low res Vive headset monitors. Compared to other Vive action games, everything seemed clear and more than I was hoping for diving into this game. Because of the environment and sound effects, you instantly get sucked into the game and forget that you are in VR. After the latest updates from the dev, the directional sounds has been greatly improved, and bugs are less occouring.

CONTROLS
First thing I want to address is the touchpad movement. I have tried many other titles with touchpad movement and instantly get motion sick. In this game I don't. I'm not sure how this was accomplished, but kudos to the dev. The fact that you need to physically crouch or lay down to do so in the game feels great and ads to the immersion. Swapping between equipment took a few minutes to get the hang of, but quickly became intuitive.

PERFORMANCE
I properly don't have the right to say that this game performed perfectly since I own a GTX 1080. But I experienced no low frame rates as of yet except for the darker maps when using night vision. But the dev already warned about this so if you have low system specs it might be a bad idea to play those maps.

TO THE DEVELOPER
Thank you so much for making this game available to the VR community :) This is the only game as of yet that TRULY let people experience what VR has the potential for in games that aren't just "tech demos". The fact that it is a multiplayer game only makes it even more impressive.

25248317.review:
What can I say about Onward that hasn't been said already? This game is what the Vive had us imagining when we all first laid eyes on it. Gamers knew Virtual Reality was always going to come to this point and after the initial waves of content have died down, now it is here. Playing Onward feels like stepping into the future of games; a gameworld where real-life military tactics, aim and coordination matter. I have been testing this game for a little over a month now and there is a reason I have 121 hours on record: Its that good. 

No other Vive game has held my interest for so long, or had me so dreading taking OFF the headset to 1. charge my controllers or 2. sleep/work. 

It is to me the DOOM MP, or CounterStrike of VR. In the current game mode its one life and your gear, an objective to complete or defend and your team-mates. The bullets flying, grenades exploding and frantic radio chatter will all but convince you that you are in an actual war fighting for your survival. The movement system is a slap-in-the-face to nay-sayers who think artifical locomotion cannot work in VR titles. You simply have to try it to believe how well it DOES work. Gunplay is very faithful and realistic, not overblown in the effects nor the sound department. Positional-based sounds and voice seals the deal when I can literally hear my enemies on the upper floor of a building planning their next move, or I can hear the breath of a terrified conscript hiding behind a doorway (he's listening to your footsteps too...). 

You BECOME the soldier. It is completely immersive and makes me throw my body onto the floor and against the walls trying to dodge bullets and hop behind cover in my room-scale. There have been times during my play where I truly felt I had a traumatic memory written from a situation I had just experienced in the game, because my subconscious was tricked into believing I would lose my life for real-- THAT WAS AWESOME! THAT is immersion!! At times you will feel ALL-powerful-- at times you will feel completely helpless-- but you will ALWAYS have fun. I've never felt my heart race faster while gaming, this is simply a new plateau of VR experience to live up to for future games.

The replayability, content and community for this game will keep it going strong for a long time, even if Dante chose to stop developing right now. But he's not, this is just the beginning for this game. I cannot wait to see what it grows into. For now, if you're on the fence-- treat yourself to one of the Vive's signature titles and get on the ride: it is already well worth the admission.

25248196.review:
TLDR; This game is very immersive, has good mechanics and solid gameplay, it just needs a little polishing. If you're happy to play a game that is good, but just requires some extra lovin' that is likely coming then pick this up. 7/10

Gameplay: The ability to kill/be killed is definitely there, and you feel every bullet wizzing past your head. The guns feel good and require manual operation, such as reloading and using the cocking lever, but it isn't so precise that you feel like you're trying to do surgery with marshmellows on your fingers. The balance and leeway is really good. My only two real issues with combat are that if you want to use your map you need to put all your guns away (So you can't be holding a handgun in one hand and a map in the other), and [strike]that if you die at the start of a round you have to stand over your dead body until the round ends (Could be up to 15 minutes) without being able to watch the fight[/strike] I was just informed this was me being 'injured' and that I could have been revived from this position, fair enough! Bonus: There are a lot of options for preference, such as left or right handed, pistol position (Chest/Thigh), how items are gripped, and the like.

Visuals: It isn't the prettiest game, but that doesn't affect it that much for me- If anything the distinction between the surroundings and the people is low enough that you can be sneaky, but not so low that you can't pick out targets on a bright day. The textures are not photorealistic, but they're adequate to me, however, the level design isn't perfect (Its fine. I wouldn't say its good or bad, but fine) and there is an issue with the terrain on one map, however, I've never had an issue with being stuck or unable to get where I want to go.

Controls: The controls are a little-bit fumbly and unsure at times, but when it works it works quite well; Its easy to switch weapons and use the items on your belt, however, I have had difficulty returning items to my belt (Like when I decide to try to throw a grenade, then remember what happened to my lightbulb last time and try to put it away), but actually using items is usually very good. Walking is fluid and uses a 'press a direction on the thumbpad to drift that way' movement system. It works well and you can move in any direction regardless of the direction you're facing, however, the distiction between running and walking is kind of gray and I had to learn how to move faster than a mildly panicked stroll in the middle of gunfights, but once you learn that holding your gun downwards makes you move faster (I understand the reasoning, but I think its a clunky and unintuitive implementation) it makes it a lot easier.

Multiplayer/Latency: The multiplayer seems solid, I didn't have lag issues and voices were generally pretty clear. The only real issue I had was the in-game menu during the lobby, where the wrong number of players would be placed in the wrong teams (This occasionally transferred into game, to the surprise of our now five-man squad) but this is usually mitigated by people just saying when they're actually ready. 

Overall: A good game, and a very solid base. It feels like a game that has a lot of love put into it, but lacks the finishing touch. This is totally excusable, in my opinion, given that its early access, however, I'm still going to judge it as the product it is now, not excusing it for any issues. This still leaves it at a healthy 7/10, with room to push it up to 10 if the above are addressed, and ideally more game modes and maps are added. Still, its very fun for what it is now, despite that I'd say the price would be more appropriate at about 2/3rds of what it is now.

An amazing multiplayer experience!

Update: Still amazing. They have done a lot of updates and expanded the solo missions to every map. I love the solo experience. I can now throw my plate carrier on and move through the solo missions, great training aid!

I have been looking forward to Onward since I heard of its development and it is a major factor for me purchasing the HTC Vive. I spent four years in the United States Army Infantry and deployed to Mosul, Iraq and Baquba, Iraq. I was excited for Onward not only as a gamer who would enjoy it for the fun but also as a Combat Veteran who, like many, need that itch scratched as good as it can from time to time. Onward has scratched that itch and I am excited to see where the developer takes the game as it progresses.

This game can really be whatever you want it to be, depending on the type of players you get into a server. You can move slowly in a stack throughout the level and move as a team. Or, like I did in the ship map, you can use violence of action and storm straight through on your own eliminating enemy players as you go. It's up to you and what your team wants to tolerate.

One of my favorite moments was sneaking up to a stacked enemy-fireteam coming from behind a wall. I opened up my PKM and took a couple of them out, or did they go to the prone? It was hard to tell, just like a real-world scenario. Shots started to impact around me and I took cover behind an ambulance. I could hear the enemy yelling expletives at me from behind his wall. They kept shooting at me and I kept shooting at them, the rounds ricocheting off the cover. I've been out of the military for about 6 years, so when they executed a text-book flanking maneuver and hit me from the side I was really impressed!

The radio system is perfect and an accurate representation of real-world. You can speak normally to those around you without pushing any buttons but to communicated over a distance you need to reach up to your shoulder and push the radio button. You can also hear enemies talking if you are close which really gives the atmosphere an eerily awesome vibe.

As much as I love some of the other shooters for the Vive, Onward has perfected the rifle manipulations. Magazines are easy to change and the rifle is easy to charge and sling. I can almost smell the spent shell-casings lying in the sand and the aftermath of a grenade impact. 

Character models are great and show standing, sitting and IIRC in the prone. I love being able to drop into the prone when taking contact, conduct an ambush or shoot over barriers. The movement is fluid.

Player hit-detection appears spot-on and there is great pleasure when mowing down an enemy fire-team with a PKM. The player's heal/revive system with the shot of adrenaline works well. 

I have never been prone to motion-sickness and I have hated the teleportation system in just about every other Vive game. Onward's movement system is awesome, easy to use and will likely change the face of Vive movement forever. I can understand that some may get motion sickness, but if Dante wants to address that I hope he can make teleportation-only servers or something so the rest of us can use the smooth-movement system he's implemented. 


Onward is fantastic but it does have some very minor flaws. I'm happy to see that out of about 200 reviews, only 10 are negative and largely due to players with a 980Ti having performance issues. While Dante said he is releasing a patch to fix this, I have had no issues with my 980Ti so I suspect these negative reviews are having graphical issues due to their collection of hardware and not just a single card. 

One minor game inaccuracy that I ran into is using the M249 SAW. My controllers will hit each-other and I cannot pull the charging handle to the rear, easily to load the weapon. (Also, the M249 SAW fires from the open-bolt, Dante! :)  Although, having been an M240 gunner by trade this bothers me when I'm sure nobody else even notices, so it's no biggie. ;)   )

Overall, this is a fantastic game. The fact that Dante pulled it off largely by himself is an amazing feat and worthy of the praise his masterpiece is receiving. Fantastic job and I look forward to see what you do with the place!
